[{'account_id': 32787, 'date': '2021-03-10 11:09:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 32787, 'date': '2021-03-10 11:16:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 32787, 'date': '2021-03-10 11:20:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 32787, 'date': '2021-03-10 11:33:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 32787, 'date': '2021-03-10 15:13:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 32787, 'date': '2021-03-10 15:46:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 32787, 'date': '2021-03-11 08:13:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7: New patch set was added with same tree, parent, and commit message as Patch Set 6.'}, {'account_id': 32787, 'date': '2021-03-11 12:49:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 10969, 'date': '2021-03-11 21:24:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 10969, 'date': '2021-03-11 21:25:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 10969, 'date': '2021-03-11 21:30:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 27900, 'date': '2021-03-16 08:11:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

I dislike "mode", even it is same in the aws_s3 module. It doesn't fit into our usage pattern.
What if:
- object_info module to get info/metadata/permission of the object, but not the object data (the last one is debatable)
- object module (still keeping for backward compat current operation style, but be extended):
  - add src/dest attributes
  - depending on which one of src/dest looks or is a file put or get the data. I.e. user might set "name" and src meaning upload, "name" and dest meaning download
  - make "filename" an alias to src to keep backward compatibility 
  - set metadata and all the other stuff

This way we would be able to provide the missing functionality keeping current patterns'}, {'account_id': 32787, 'date': '2021-03-17 21:42:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 10969, 'date': '2021-03-18 02:27:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Patch Set 9 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 32787, 'date': '2021-03-18 07:52:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-11-04 09:03:33.000000000', 'message': "Use py3 as the default runtime for tox

Moving on py3 as the default runtime for tox to avoid to update this at
each new cycle.

Wallaby support officially the following runtimes [1]:
- Python 3.6
- Python 3.8

During Victoria Python 3.7 was used as the default runtime [2] however this
version isn't longer officially supported.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/wallaby.html#python-runtimes-for-wallaby
[2] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/victoria.html#python-runtimes-for-victoria

Change-Id: I4a244fc6f2d0d614d579fb944255be728fee1d61
"}]
commit_message:
Use py3 as the default runtime for tox

Moving on py3 as the default runtime for tox to avoid to update this at
each new cycle.

Wallaby support officially the following runtimes [1]:
- Python 3.6
- Python 3.8

During Victoria Python 3.7 was used as the default runtime [2] however this
version isn't longer officially supported.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/wallaby.html#python-runtimes-for-wallaby
[2] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/victoria.html#python-runtimes-for-victoria

Change-Id: I4a244fc6f2d0d614d579fb944255be728fee1d61

Snapshot information should be retrieved from the snapshot API
instead of retrieving volume's last_snap

Though it is fixed in latest hacking but 2.0 and 3.0 has cap for

commit_message:
Fix hacking min version to 3.0.1

flake8 new release 3.8.0 added new checks and gate pep8
job start failing. hacking 3.0.1 fix the pinning of flake8 to
avoid bringing in a new version with new checks.

Though it is fixed in latest hacking but 2.0 and 3.0 has cap for
flake8 as <4.0.0 which mean flake8 new version 3.9.0 can also
break the pep8 job if new check are added.

To avoid similar gate break in future, we need to bump the hacking min
version.

- http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-May/014828.html

Change-Id: I87fdbf691c0b2b0abdf629b358d875d955b14015

[0] and there currently is a discussion on the mailing list [1]
about dropping the test, with the oslo team already having done
so [2].

The new dependency resolver in pip fails due to incompatible
dependency versions in our lower-constraints file, meaning that

commit_message:
Drop lower-constraints

Lower-constraints is not a requirement of the OpenStack Python PTI
[0] and there currently is a discussion on the mailing list [1]
about dropping the test, with the oslo team already having done
so [2].

The new dependency resolver in pip fails due to incompatible
dependency versions in our lower-constraints file, meaning that
we were never providing any real guarantees with it.

To unblock the CI, I am disabling lower-constraints job for now,
with the option to reenable it in case we fix the constraints,
and based on the outcome of the mailing list discussions and
consensus.

[0]. https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/pti/python.html
[1].
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-January/019672.html
[2].
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-January/019659.html

Change-Id: I04e49f005841eb341c2d53cbc469252c089d1ab5

commit_message:
bindep: Add 'librdkafka-dev' dependency

We're seeing the following in our build logs:

    In file included from confluent_kafka/src/confluent_kafka.c:17:0:
    confluent_kafka/src/confluent_kafka.h:22:10: fatal error: librdkafka/rdkafka.h: No such file or directory
     #include <librdkafka/rdkafka.h>
              ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
    compilation terminated.
    error: command 'x86_64-linux-gnu-gcc' failed with exit status 1

Resolve this by installing the development headers.

Change-Id: Idda79dc87bcd0e3367a6abd1b52104c000ad1dcd
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Use TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE

UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE is old name and deprecated
This allows to use upper-constraints file as more
readable way instead of UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE=<lower-constraints file>.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/722814/
[2] https://zuul-ci.org/docs/zuul-jobs/python-roles.html#rolevar-tox.tox_constraints_file

Change-Id: I1a006cf4368cc18c34dd6f236ecfe966e6b09388

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/wallaby

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/wallaby branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I98c165315be4620a3046632e9c126138236bcf81

[{'created': '2020-11-04 09:02:14.000000000', 'message': "Use py3 as the default runtime for tox

Moving on py3 as the default runtime for tox to avoid to update this at
each new cycle.

Wallaby support officially the following runtimes [1]:
- Python 3.6
- Python 3.8

During Victoria Python 3.7 was used as the default runtime [2] however this
version isn't longer officially supported.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/wallaby.html#python-runtimes-for-wallaby
[2] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/victoria.html#python-runtimes-for-victoria

Change-Id: I8042501ae7a721c9fb6cb469799e2186f7dbf7ac
"}]
commit_message:
Use py3 as the default runtime for tox

Moving on py3 as the default runtime for tox to avoid to update this at
each new cycle.

Wallaby support officially the following runtimes [1]:
- Python 3.6
- Python 3.8

During Victoria Python 3.7 was used as the default runtime [2] however this
version isn't longer officially supported.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/wallaby.html#python-runtimes-for-wallaby
[2] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/victoria.html#python-runtimes-for-victoria

Change-Id: I8042501ae7a721c9fb6cb469799e2186f7dbf7ac

commit_message:
Dropping lower constraints testing

We facing errors related to the new pip resolver, this
topic was discussed on the ML and QA team proposed to
to test lower-constraints [1].

I propose to drop this test because the complexity and recurring pain needed
to maintain that now exceeds the benefits provided by this mechanismes.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-December/019390.html

NOTE(stephenfin): This also includes change
I9ffd46865477b3fa7d43258d67dd0ec224ee6467 ("Move flake8 as a pre-commit
local target.") which is also needed to get the requirements job
passing.

Change-Id: I62d911111b54976a9df726c48f593a52e275fe6c
(cherry picked from commit 90b5daaa9c48edf9ef1b09c31163d135b71155b3)

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/wallaby

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/wallaby branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I4f35a2625445929c0d220d2cad461315623e920c

commit_message:
Dropping lower constraints testing

We facing errors related to the new pip resolver, this
topic was discussed on the ML and QA team proposed to
to test lower-constraints [1].

I propose to drop this test because the complexity and recurring pain needed
to maintain that now exceeds the benefits provided by this mechanismes.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-December/019390.html

NOTE(stephenfin): This also includes change
Ie89835eb10a2211abad4d67b23ea8165daca37d2 ("Move flake8 as a pre-commit
local target") since both are needed to pass the requirements job.

Change-Id: Ied61e65006ad54803453776e763594e216be1353
(cherry picked from commit e8062fc9e3e6b43c426bdba1d8425ee8635ba976)

commit_message:
[K8S] Enable --use-service-account-credentials

Enable the config --use-service-account-credentials=true. This is
necessary to support Pod Security Policy[1].

See
https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/command-line-tools-reference/kube-controller-manager/
for the option description, and more information here[2].

[1]: https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/policy/pod-security-policy/#troubleshooting
[2]: https://docs.datadoghq.com/security_monitoring/default_rules/cis-kubernetes-1.5.1-1.3.3/

Change-Id: I053808fac72a63af7ebf6f33d94659134b6cbdac
(cherry picked from commit e9b48896703dabd3aac78c48f6c0c9d5489a534e)

commit_message:
Adding technical details about the memcache pool backend.

This backend lack of documentation and technical details.
Many people think that this the memcache pool backend is going to be HA
and think that values are replicated.

The added details try to give more details about how this backend works
under the hood.

Change-Id: If9056168aacca85ae072172ec203319af42962d8

commit_message:
Cap tenacity to unblock the gate

Recent version 7 changed retry and dropped the
retry_state parameter.

Also fixed a conflict between pre-commit hook and tox.ini where
hacking was just conflicting

Also fixed .gitreview to point to stable/wallaby for wallaby branch.

Change-Id: I109d3b5770c3cd8fe0bdeae78517f4d36ba3b65f
(cherry picked from commit f2005df3d6565e050e4ca710df4eda518353b9c2)

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-04-15 14:39:05.000000000', 'message': "Fix requirements issues

This patch is the merge of 2 current fixes that need to be solved in the
same time. Indeed each issue lock our gates independently.

Dropping lower constraints testing

We facing errors related to the new pip resolver, this
topic was discussed on the ML and QA team proposed to
to test lower-constraints [1].

I propose to drop this test because the complexity and recurring pain needed
to maintain that now exceeds the benefits provided by this mechanismes.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-December/019390.html

Move flake8 as a pre-commit local target.

The goal here is to avoid conflicts between flake8 and hacking version each
2 days.

Inspired from nova's approach[1].

The flake8 version to install will be determined by hacking and
requirements[2] will stay aligned instead of relying on different versions.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/src/branch/master/.pre-commit-config.yaml#L26-L35
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/hacking/src/branch/master/requirements.txt#L1

Co-authored-by: Hervé Beraud <hberaud@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I2f41e05df1cc978821bf7cb6d9a95bf543c7fba3
(cherry picked from commit 5c806d492b22f25b79e6598b2fe3847ba6963220)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix requirements issues

This patch is the merge of 2 current fixes that need to be solved in the
same time. Indeed each issue lock our gates independently.

Dropping lower constraints testing

We facing errors related to the new pip resolver, this
topic was discussed on the ML and QA team proposed to
to test lower-constraints [1].

I propose to drop this test because the complexity and recurring pain needed
to maintain that now exceeds the benefits provided by this mechanismes.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-December/019390.html

Move flake8 as a pre-commit local target.

The goal here is to avoid conflicts between flake8 and hacking version each
2 days.

Inspired from nova's approach[1].

The flake8 version to install will be determined by hacking and
requirements[2] will stay aligned instead of relying on different versions.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/src/branch/master/.pre-commit-config.yaml#L26-L35
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/hacking/src/branch/master/requirements.txt#L1

Co-authored-by: Hervé Beraud <hberaud@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I2f41e05df1cc978821bf7cb6d9a95bf543c7fba3
(cherry picked from commit 5c806d492b22f25b79e6598b2fe3847ba6963220)

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/wallaby

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/wallaby branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I5584b480a617b8ec8b1cbdad5054a5775cec3a7d

subject: Fixed exception handling of the print_tuple_table method.
messages:
[{'account_id': 32926, 'date': '2021-04-07 13:19:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11491, 'date': '2021-04-08 04:29:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Jiri,

Why not squashing this patch with https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/validations-common/+/785186?

Both are fixing the same subject in the same file and in the very same function. I think it would better to squash them both, find out a global commit title and add the explanation about KeyError/IndexError ...

What do you think?'}, {'account_id': 32926, 'date': '2021-04-08 07:35:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Patch Set 1:
> 
> Jiri,
> 
> Why not squashing this patch with https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/validations-common/+/785186?
> 
> Both are fixing the same subject in the same file and in the very same function. I think it would better to squash them both, find out a global commit title and add the explanation about KeyError/IndexError ...
> 
> What do you think?

I do see the point. On the other hand, this is meant to be a quick fix for an issue that's effectively rendering entire code branch incapable of handling exceptions. Not a general refactoring of the module, or even the method.
Not that it isn't something we'll have to do at some point."}, {'account_id': 32926, 'date': '2021-04-08 07:48:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 32926, 'date': '2021-04-08 07:49:00.000000000', 'content': 'Topic tuplekeyerror removed'}, {'account_id': 32926, 'date': '2021-04-08 07:49:09.000000000', 'content': 'Topic set to exceptionhandling'}, {'account_id': 32926, 'date': '2021-04-15 12:58:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 27427, 'date': '2021-04-15 17:37:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

The commit message seems to indicate more to this patch; I only see the change related to the RuntimeError.  What's the story?"}, {'account_id': 32926, 'date': '2021-04-16 07:00:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> Patch Set 3:
> 
> The commit message seems to indicate more to this patch; I only see the change related to the RuntimeError.  What's the story?

Changes got mixed between this one and the followup patch. Will fix today."}, {'account_id': 32926, 'date': '2021-04-16 12:43:05.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Now part of https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/validations-common/+/786640'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-04-07 13:19:28.000000000', 'message': "KeyError was changed to IndexError

Tuples don't have keys so the KeyError couldn't have
occured under any circumstances.

IndexError, on the other hand, can.

Signed-off-by: Jiri Podivin <jpodivin@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Id2578897f35b5ea0845488ec7942e6ae364f0ee5
"}, {'created': '2021-04-08 07:48:10.000000000', 'message': "Fixed exception handling of the print_tuple_table method.

KeyError was changed to IndexError
ValueError was changed to KeyError

Tuples don't have keys so the KeyError couldn't have
occured under any circumstances.

IndexError, on the other hand, can.

ValueError couldn't have been raised by the code.
KeyError is more appropriate in the context.

Signed-off-by: Jiri Podivin <jpodivin@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Id2578897f35b5ea0845488ec7942e6ae364f0ee5
"}, {'created': '2021-04-15 12:58:25.000000000', 'message': "Fixed exception handling of the print_tuple_table method.

KeyError was changed to IndexError
ValueError was changed to KeyError

Tuples don't have keys so the KeyError couldn't have
occured under any circumstances.

IndexError, on the other hand, can.

ValueError couldn't have been raised by the code.
KeyError is more appropriate in the context.

RuntimeError was replaced with more fitting TypeError.

Signed-off-by: Jiri Podivin <jpodivin@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Id2578897f35b5ea0845488ec7942e6ae364f0ee5
"}]
commit_message:
Fixed exception handling of the print_tuple_table method.

KeyError was changed to IndexError
ValueError was changed to KeyError

Tuples don't have keys so the KeyError couldn't have
occured under any circumstances.

IndexError, on the other hand, can.

ValueError couldn't have been raised by the code.
KeyError is more appropriate in the context.

RuntimeError was replaced with more fitting TypeError.

Signed-off-by: Jiri Podivin <jpodivin@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Id2578897f35b5ea0845488ec7942e6ae364f0ee5

commit_message:
Update master for stable/wallaby

Add file to the reno documentation build to show release notes for
stable/wallaby.

Use pbr instruction to increment the minor version number
automatically so that master versions are higher than the versions on
stable/wallaby.

Sem-Ver: feature
Change-Id: Ic4f96634aa7fe3080c46ef411b7d47778676af1b

commit_message:
strutils: Stop masking encryption_key_id

As the name suggests this is simply an id referring to a key and not the
actual key itself. As such we should stop masking this in an effort to
ease debugging and troubleshooting when it is logged.

This was previously incorrectly masked by
I9e684cd8bab85728ff0117f95a30eb7dbb5bf51c as part of bug #1814365.

Closes-Bug: #1905264
Change-Id: I856e3cf32c409debdfb15aa96415c3309fe2f516

commit_message:
Dropping lower constraints testing

We facing errors related to the new pip resolver, this
topic was discussed on the ML and QA team proposed to
to test lower-constraints [1].

I propose to drop this test because the complexity and recurring pain
needed to maintain that now exceeds the benefits provided by this
mechanisms.

Also removing lower constraints and related tox environment as they are
no longer needed.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-December/019390.html

Conflicts:
  lower-constraints.txt

NOTE(stephenfin): Conflicts are due to different constraints in
lower-constraints.

Change-Id: Icf48ef72fbfff88dda2714b386dbbfe355dc1acb
(cherry picked from commit 686a8b61826d9bed0a989e645a13c708c3e6343c)
(cherry picked from commit 1682ef69ae30732071fb4296f947047c37c4622e)

commit_message:
Unblock wallaby gate

This is a combination of 2 commits that both needed to unblock
stable/wallaby gate:

1. Remove contradictions in lower-constraints

This will avoid the following issue seen recently on wallaby and on
projects where lower-constraints tests haven't been yet dropped:

```
ERROR: Could not find a version that satisfies the requirement
bandit<1.7.0,>=1.6.0
ERROR: No matching distribution found for bandit<1.7.0,>=1.6.0
```

Also some other packages lower constraints has to bump to avoid
further contradictions and slow run of the pip resolver.

2. move flake8 as a pre-commit local target

The goal here is to avoid conflicts between flake8 and hacking version each
2 days.

Inspired from nova's approach [1].

The flake8 version to install will be determined by hacking and
requirements will stay aligned instead of relying on different versions.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/src/branch/master/.pre-commit-config.yaml#L26-L35
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/hacking/src/branch/master/requirements.txt#L1

Conflicts:
    pre-commit-config.yaml

(NOTE) hberaud: Original commit was made on the top of intermediary
changes on master.

Change-Id: Iae20f13ba6293b94b5bd131941263e097eba0518
(cherry picked from commit 7443bcd079e1c52e8527b5f4b9ce1431aa7cf317)

subject: Correctly handle IO errors at policy file load
messages:
[{'account_id': 27838, 'date': '2019-07-12 14:27:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2019-07-12 15:20:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I'm curious why this is a silent error right now. I don't see anywhere that we would catch the IOError, so presumably it would bubble up to the service. Is one of the services swallowing it?

Or is it because https://github.com/openstack/oslo.policy/blob/b9fd10e2612f26c93d49c168a0408aba6d20e5bf/oslo_policy/policy.py#L559 is a debug message so it won't be logged at normal log levels? If the policy file is in the default location with incorrect permissions that might cause a silent failure. If this is the case then the change won't help because we never get to that code.

I think it would be helpful to have more details about the problem. Can you open a bug describing the scenario that is misbehaving for you? Things like which service, the policy values in that service's configuration file, that sort of thing."}, {'account_id': 27838, 'date': '2019-07-12 15:43:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

In our case this issue affects Horizon. Here https://github.com/openstack/horizon/blob/master/openstack_auth/policy.py#L67 we get unhandled IOError if policy file is present, but permission is too restricting. As a result, policy check fails. Oslo.config implements proper ConfigFilesPermissionDeniedError exception, but it is never used in oslo.policy. Also, impact of issue on Horizon strongly depends on options and setup: Horizon run by manage.py and DEBUG=True crashes with the whole traceback, but prod-like setup with Apache and limited logging fails silently'}, {'account_id': 27838, 'date': '2019-07-12 16:04:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2019-07-12 18:56:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Hmm, first off I feel like Horizon should not be silently swallowing an exception from a policy failure in any logging configuration. That's an error which needs to be reported in some way.

I also have concerns about fixing it this way. While it will result in a log message indicating a problem, it also returns bogus data to the policy check which I believe will result in the default policy-in-code rules being used. This could be serious problem for deployers with policy overrides as it may result in a user getting permission to something they shouldn't.

Would adding the log message but changing the return to still raise an exception address your concerns? That way the problem definitely gets logged, but we don't claim to have loaded a file that we actually didn't.

I will also note that we need to be careful about logging in this library because there are so many policy calls made. This seems okay to me since it only happens in legitimate error situations that need to be resolved quickly, but I'd appreciate other reviewers giving it some thought too just in case I've missed something."}, {'account_id': 27838, 'date': '2019-07-15 14:32:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 27838, 'date': '2019-07-15 14:32:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Added exception raise, but not sure if it an optimal way'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2019-07-16 15:04:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Hello,

First, thanks for these changes.

I'm not sure to see all the possible impacts of these changes, but they LGTM in a functional thinking.

Some unit test would be welcome too.

Also I've some comments inline (the rationale of my -1):"}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2019-07-16 21:16:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4: Patch Set 3 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2019-07-16 21:23:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

I've added some unit tests on this module through Ife6600da240f830aa0080e3f214cedf1389ea512 so I rebase your patch on my changes to surround this module with some tests.

When you will apply the requested changes I will added some tests to surround the PermissionError on test too."}, {'account_id': 27838, 'date': '2019-07-17 11:19:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2019-07-17 13:26:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: -Code-Review

(1 comment)

Hello Vadym,

Thanks for your explaination. We need to keep compat with py2.7.'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2019-07-17 13:28:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2019-07-17 14:35:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Some comments inline'}, {'account_id': 27838, 'date': '2019-07-19 11:28:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2019-07-19 13:57:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2019-07-19 16:14:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

FWIW, I don't think we need to go this granular with the error handling. I actually think it might be a little unintuitive if we only handle very specific errors when loading a policy file. Consumers of this library won't know whether they need to log a message or not without also looking at the exact error that is raised. I'd rather just handle exceptions from the cache file load or not. If we want more specific log messages for some exceptions then that's fine too, but that could be done as a followup to this.

One other thing about the logging inline."}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2020-08-18 17:08:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2021-02-08 16:29:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2

Sorry for not getting back to this sooner. My main concerns have been addressed, so lgtm. Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2021-02-09 14:32:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6: Patch Set 5 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2021-02-09 14:33:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-12 14:27:14.000000000', 'message': 'Correctly handle IO errors at policy file load

For now, policy file unaccessible due to access permission leads to
silent failure without any notifictaion. Side effects of it are also
affected by policy caching and might be quite confusing, like periodic
disappearing of Horizon panels. Proposed patch added handling of such
errors.

commit_message:
Correctly handle IO errors at policy file load

For now, policy file unaccessible due to access permission leads to
silent failure without any notifictaion. Side effects of it are also
affected by policy caching and might be quite confusing, like periodic
disappearing of Horizon panels. Proposed patch added handling of such
errors.

Closes-bug: #1836390
Change-Id: I0d67b6e7c2dcaa63d6bb807f013e5e7334efc715

commit_message:
Reinstate double deprecation test logic

This was lost in a previous change, but in the interest of not holding
up the merge of the functional part of it I'm fixing the test in this
followup. The new version of the test verifies that the rule isn't
overwritten by a second call to load_rules, which is what would
happen if we called the deprecation handler again.

Change-Id: Idc9dd353463da63a2108782f7b141d1d8014d180

commit_message:
Improving documentation about target resources

Sometimes it's not easy to identify the target resource based on the API call.

Adding some more details on how API attribute is used as a targer, with an
example on how to compare the API calls logs with the target resource would
help to debug policy issues.

Change-Id: I1318cceb5c0a32c258e6799a872a5dea6482c6de
Closes-Bug: #1886857

commit_message:
Use TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE

UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE is old name and deprecated
This allows to use upper-constraints file as more
readable way instead of UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE=<lower-constraints file>.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/722814/
[2] https://zuul-ci.org/docs/zuul-jobs/python-roles.html#rolevar-tox.tox_constraints_file

Change-Id: If7d6b78ce39b9d629095ed461f0cb154ed6ed9bf

commit_message:
Move zuul jobs to system-config queue

As we observed that the default use of tripleo queue make changes
made to this repository to wait in line with other (hours), we move
it to system-config queue in order to fast-track them.

This is needed because almost all changes expected to be made inside
this repository are changes to the list of queries we use to identify
CI job failures, and they need to merge as soon as posible.

Change-Id: Ic53815dc6f9584bed5ba903b5825be48d3d62763

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-02-01 10:36:32.000000000', 'message': "Switch to collections.abc.*

The abstract base classes previously defined in 'collections' were moved
to 'collections.abc' in 3.3. The aliases will be removed in 3.10.
Preempt this change now with a simple find-replace:

  $ ag -l 'collections.($TYPES)' | \
      xargs sed -i 's/\(collections\)\.\($TYPES\)/\1.abc.\2/g'

Where $TYPES is the list of moved ABCs from [1].

[1] https://docs.python.org/3/library/collections.abc.html

Change-Id: I85f2757852c0313967f5d82166124feb10aa4c6a
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
"}]
commit_message:
Switch to collections.abc.*

The abstract base classes previously defined in 'collections' were moved
to 'collections.abc' in 3.3. The aliases will be removed in 3.10.
Preempt this change now with a simple find-replace:

  $ ag -l 'collections.($TYPES)' | \
      xargs sed -i 's/\(collections\)\.\($TYPES\)/\1.abc.\2/g'

Where $TYPES is the list of moved ABCs from [1].

[1] https://docs.python.org/3/library/collections.abc.html

Change-Id: I85f2757852c0313967f5d82166124feb10aa4c6a
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/wallaby

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/wallaby branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I711fb7f9a54ababd7eeaee5297e220ac872e7bff

subject: Use py3 as the default runtime for tox
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-01-21 14:34:46.000000000', 'message': "Use py3 as the default runtime for tox

Moving on py3 as the default runtime for tox to avoid to update this at
each new cycle.

Wallaby support officially the following runtimes [1]:
- Python 3.6
- Python 3.8

During Victoria Python 3.7 was used as the default runtime [2] however
this version isn't longer officially supported.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/wallaby.html#python-runtimes-for-wallaby
[2] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/victoria.html#python-runtimes-for-victoria

Change-Id: I0fbe297ed98bbf7d302ce055418f35da604158a0
"}]
commit_message:
Use py3 as the default runtime for tox

Moving on py3 as the default runtime for tox to avoid to update this at
each new cycle.

Wallaby support officially the following runtimes [1]:
- Python 3.6
- Python 3.8

During Victoria Python 3.7 was used as the default runtime [2] however
this version isn't longer officially supported.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/wallaby.html#python-runtimes-for-wallaby
[2] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/victoria.html#python-runtimes-for-victoria

Change-Id: I0fbe297ed98bbf7d302ce055418f35da604158a0

commit_message:
Remove RBD swap disk if resizing to a flavor without swap

If you boot an instance with swap > 0 and images_type of rbd and then
resize it to a flavor without swap, the swap rbd image will not be
deleted. Correct this.

Change-Id: I72251ab24f4ada85665866a42a134d646423d484
Signed-off-by: Chen Hanxiao <chenhx@certusnet.com.cn>

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/wallaby

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/wallaby branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I2fce79689ae625184566fd980b9ab2c1de5ed379

commit_message:
Move flake8 as a pre-commit local target.

The goal here is to avoid conflicts between flake8 and hacking version each
2 days.

Inspired from nova's approach[1].

The flake8 version to install will be determined by hacking and
requirements[2] will stay aligned instead of relying on different versions.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/src/branch/master/.pre-commit-config.yaml#L26-L35
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/hacking/src/branch/master/requirements.txt#L1

Change-Id: Ie89835eb10a2211abad4d67b23ea8165daca37d2
(cherry picked from commit a1ecfaa872b0e60f0202e812d152ce97adeb8a69)

commit_message:
Move flake8 as a pre-commit local target.

The goal here is to avoid conflicts between flake8 and hacking version each
2 days.

Inspired from nova's approach[1].

The flake8 version to install will be determined by hacking and
requirements[2] will stay aligned instead of relying on different versions.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/src/branch/master/.pre-commit-config.yaml#L26-L35
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/hacking/src/branch/master/requirements.txt#L1

Change-Id: I9ffd46865477b3fa7d43258d67dd0ec224ee6467
(cherry picked from commit 53838531bea6d106c6515b1aeec41fd86f0e23af)

subject: Fix hacking min version to 3.0.1
messages: [{'account_id': 30092, 'date': '2020-12-31 01:16:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2021-04-16 10:42:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-12-31 01:16:31.000000000', 'message': 'Fix hacking min version to 3.0.1

flake8 new release 3.8.0 added new checks and gate pep8
job start failing. hacking 3.0.1 fix the pinning of flake8 to
avoid bringing in a new version with new checks.

Though it is fixed in latest hacking but 2.0 and 3.0 has cap for
flake8 as <4.0.0 which mean flake8 new version 3.9.0 can also
break the pep8 job if new check are added.

To avoid similar gate break in future, we need to bump the hacking min
version.

- http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-May/014828.html

Change-Id: I4c0088e31a8f8e3120a473f0e362445f5b3fe5cf
'}]
commit_message:
Fix hacking min version to 3.0.1

flake8 new release 3.8.0 added new checks and gate pep8
job start failing. hacking 3.0.1 fix the pinning of flake8 to
avoid bringing in a new version with new checks.

Though it is fixed in latest hacking but 2.0 and 3.0 has cap for
flake8 as <4.0.0 which mean flake8 new version 3.9.0 can also
break the pep8 job if new check are added.

To avoid similar gate break in future, we need to bump the hacking min
version.

- http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-May/014828.html

Change-Id: I4c0088e31a8f8e3120a473f0e362445f5b3fe5cf

commit_message:
Use TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE

UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE is old name and deprecated
This allows to use upper-constraints file as more
readable way instead of UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE=<lower-constraints file>.

Change-Id: I760c60ff837fb51bda382780941ed6a2d2110e3c

subject: Add default_fn= to Field
messages:
[{'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2020-01-09 18:15:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2020-01-09 18:47:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2020-01-10 12:23:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

(2 comments)

While I have a clear use case for the EphemeralObject feature in the parent class I don't have a similar immediate need for the default_fn feature in this class. Besides the above, the interface contract and the implementation of the default_fn feature look OK to me."}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2020-01-10 12:25:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2020-01-10 16:37:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> While I have a clear use case for the EphemeralObject feature in
 > the parent class I don't have a similar immediate need for the
 > default_fn feature in this class. Besides the above, the interface
 > contract and the implementation of the default_fn feature look OK
 > to me.

Maybe I confused the situation a bit by calling it a function, but what I was really going for was allowing for the syntactic sugar of just providing a type as the default_fn, which means "the default for this field is an empty $object of this type".

Right now, to do that, we have to provide a whole instance of that type of object, which will be deepcopy'd when the default is set, which is pretty silly. Originally our field types were almost all primitives (integers and the like) and so this behaved pretty much like argument defaults in python. However, we have a lot more objects and complexity these days, so this was an attempt to provide a more flexible interface.

We do not have to merge this patch if people don't think it's worth it.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2020-01-10 16:41:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2020-01-15 15:39:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2021-04-16 10:48:17.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

There hasn't been an update on this in some time. I think it's safe to say this can be abandoned. Please let us know if you want to pick this up again"}]

Change-Id: Ie2c20c73cb90ac24877c44ae8c9bb60fa9b5085b

Change-Id: Ie2c20c73cb90ac24877c44ae8c9bb60fa9b5085b
'}, {'created': '2020-01-10 16:41:07.000000000', 'message': 'Add default_fn= to Field

This adds a new mechanism for providing defaults for fields, which takes
a function instead of a value. To retain compatibility with existing code,
this does not attempt to make handling of default= magical to determine
if the default is callable. Because classes are callable, this also allows

Change-Id: Ie2c20c73cb90ac24877c44ae8c9bb60fa9b5085b
'}]
commit_message:
Add default_fn= to Field

This adds a new mechanism for providing defaults for fields, which takes
a function instead of a value. To retain compatibility with existing code,
this does not attempt to make handling of default= magical to determine
if the default is callable. Because classes are callable, this also allows
for defaulting a value to a class, including another object.

Change-Id: Ie2c20c73cb90ac24877c44ae8c9bb60fa9b5085b

subject: Add EphemeralObject mix-in class for sane field defaulting
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 4393, 'name': 'Dan Smith', 'email': 'dms@danplanet.com', 'username': 'danms'}, {'_account_id': 9708, 'name': 'Balazs Gibizer', 'display_name': 'gibi', 'email': 'gibizer@gmail.com', 'username': 'gibi'}, {'_account_id': 11904, 'name': 'Sean McGinnis', 'email': 'sean.mcginnis@gmail.com', 'username': 'SeanM'}, {'_account_id': 14070, 'name': 'Eric Fried', 'email': 'openstack@fried.cc', 'username': 'efried'}, {'_account_id': 15334, 'name': 'Stephen Finucane', 'display_name': 'stephenfin', 'email': 'stephenfin@redhat.com', 'username': 'sfinucan'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 26458, 'name': 'Brin Zhang', 'email': 'zhangbailin@inspur.com', 'username': 'zhangbailin'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2020-01-09 18:15:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2020-01-09 18:33:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Okay, IIUC with this approach I would need to define an EphemeralFoo(Foo, EphemeralObject) for every Foo type I want to use in this way, right?

That seems heavy, but maybe that's desirable.

As an alternative, from a consumer's point of view I feel like it would be preferable to be able to tell the field to default on init without having to define a new type. Like

 'request_level_params': fields.ObjectField('RequestLevelParams',
                                            default_fn=RequestLevelParams,
                                            default_on_init=True)

Thoughts?"}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2020-01-09 18:39:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Okay, IIUC with this approach I would need to define an
 > EphemeralFoo(Foo, EphemeralObject) for every Foo type I want to use
 > in this way, right?
 > 
 > That seems heavy, but maybe that's desirable.

It's explicit, which is why it's desirable. However, I would expect Nova to define a single class that mixes in the mix-in, and then our objects just inherit from that so they don't have to do the mixing-in themselves, but the parentage is still there. So you'd do something like


 class RequestyThing(objects.NovaEphemeralObject):
 ...

And it would be clear from the parentage that this is one of those things, without you having to mix in this special behavior into each. I could have defined the straight subclass here as well, but the way the rest of the special behaviors are in o.vo, a mix-in is the convention.

 > As an alternative, from a consumer's point of view I feel like it
 > would be preferable to be able to tell the field to default on init
 > without having to define a new type. Like
 > 
 > 'request_level_params': fields.ObjectField('RequestLevelParams',
 > default_fn=RequestLevelParams,
 > default_on_init=True)
 > 
 > Thoughts?

That's far more verbose for an object with several fields, which I would assume would get rather laborious over time. However, the important part for me is that we classify an object as "one of a type of thing that doesn't need to worry about this particular detail". We can't change the assumptions of the base object without affecting everyone, so opting out of that worry is our only compatible option.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2020-01-09 21:05:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> It's explicit
<snip>
> That's far more verbose

I don't understand how it's less explicit to make default_on_init=True (or ephemeral=True, or whatever) an initialization option like nullable and read_only are. The only difference is that the ephemeral-ness is encoded in the type name rather than in a kwarg. This:

 'my_field': ObjectField('Foo', default_fn=Foo, ephemeral=True),

is not significantly more verbose than this:

 'my_field': NovaEphemeralObjectField('Foo', default_fn=Foo),

> I would expect Nova to define a single class

But don't we need a new class per base type that we want to be ephemeral? Using the example from [1], that would mean that, in addition to the NovaEphemeralObjectField(ObjectField, EphemeralObject) and RequestLevelParams(NovaEphemeralObjectField) for RequestSpec.request_level_params, we also need a NovaEphemeralSetOfStringsField(SetOfStringsField, EphemeralObject) for RequestLevelParams.root_required and .root_forbidden.

(I may be misunderstanding exactly what level you're suggesting defining the new classes at, but I'm advocating for an approach that doesn't require new classes at all.)

> We can't change the assumptions of the base object

Agreed, but neither approach does that. The default would be ephemeral=False, which skips the obj_set_defaults on init, the legacy behavior.

(BTW, then if you really wanted to, you could still define a

 NovaEphemeralObjectField(ObjectField):
     def __init__(self, **kwargs):
         kwargs.setdefault('ephemeral', True)
         super().__init__(**kwargs)

but of course I'm advocating against that.)

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/699050/"}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2020-01-09 21:21:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Maybe we can kill two birds: default_on_init=$callable (mutually exclusive with existing default=)

/me hacks...'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2020-01-09 21:53:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> > It's explicit
 > <snip>
 > > That's far more verbose
 > 
 > I don't understand how it's less explicit to make default_on_init=True
 > (or ephemeral=True, or whatever) an initialization option like
 > nullable and read_only are. The only difference is that the
 > ephemeral-ness is encoded in the type name rather than in a kwarg.
 > This:
 > 
 > 'my_field': ObjectField('Foo', default_fn=Foo, ephemeral=True),
 > 
 > is not significantly more verbose than this:
 > 
 > 'my_field': NovaEphemeralObjectField('Foo', default_fn=Foo),

It's more verbose because I'm suggesting that fields either all be default-on-init or not based on whether or not they inherit from a class that indicates that an object is entirely ephemeral. You inherit, you get defaulting on init. You don't inherit you don't. Putting the ephemeralness on the field both (a) requires an additional (or different) flag from today on each field and (b) allows mixing of default-on-init fields with default-only-later fields on the same object. Since I don't want someone to be able to do that on, say, our Migration object for a new field they add.


 > But don't we need a new class per base type that we want to be
 > ephemeral?

No.
 > Using the example from [1], that would mean that, in
 > addition to the NovaEphemeralObjectField(ObjectField,
 > EphemeralObject) and RequestLevelParams(NovaEphemeralObjectField)
 > for RequestSpec.request_level_params, we also need a
 > NovaEphemeralSetOfStringsField(SetOfStringsField, EphemeralObject)
 > for RequestLevelParams.root_required and .root_forbidden.
 > 
 > (I may be misunderstanding exactly what level you're suggesting
 > defining the new classes at, but I'm advocating for an approach
 > that doesn't require new classes at all.)

No, definitely not. None of the fields have to be subclassed.

RequestLevelParams inherits from NovaEphemeralObject instead of NovaObject. That is the only change you need to make."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2020-01-09 22:28:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)

Okay, discussed this some more in IRC [1], and I'm convinced it's the right approach. I think we agreed to "try it out" directly in nova first.

[1] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-nova/%23openstack-nova.2020-01-09.log.html#t2020-01-09T21:40:02'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2020-01-10 11:30:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

(6 comments)

Thank you Dan!'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2020-01-10 16:34:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2020-01-15 15:23:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2020-01-15 22:06:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2020-01-15 22:08:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Workflow-1

Stephen, just FYI, we've copied this into Nova to avoid having to wait for a o.vo release to test this out. So I think we should wait for consensus there (I think we're basically there) before we put this in just so we don't have to worry about undoing it. When that happens, we can do this, release and then make nova depend on it."}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2020-03-07 19:40:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
Add EphemeralObject mix-in class for sane field defaulting

This adds a class that gives more conventional field defaulting for
objects that are RPC-only, or stored as a blob in the database.

Change-Id: I4730dd45359db54318843d2790b74d43430368ee

commit_message:
Fix hacking min version to 3.0.1

flake8 new release 3.8.0 added new checks and gate pep8
job start failing. hacking 3.0.1 fix the pinning of flake8 to
avoid bringing in a new version with new checks.

Though it is fixed in latest hacking but 2.0 and 3.0 has cap for
flake8 as <4.0.0 which mean flake8 new version 3.9.0 can also
break the pep8 job if new check are added.

To avoid similar gate break in future, we need to bump the hacking min
version.

- http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-May/014828.html

Change-Id: I85a5665b8d02ec74c695446c963ec89a76d7bbbb

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/wallaby

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/wallaby branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I63a4efdef370f03790ef0d372c13ec3c1214cdce

commit_message:
Dropping lower constraints testing

We facing errors related to the new pip resolver, this
topic was discussed on the ML and QA team proposed to
to test lower-constraints [1].

I propose to drop this test because the complexity and recurring pain needed
to maintain that now exceeds the benefits provided by this mechanismes.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-December/019390.html

NOTE(stephenfin): This change also includes change
I996bcc6952a80aaccf50bb8ade579ebd960f4292 ("Move flake8 as a pre-commit
local target.") which is also necessary to get requirements tests
passing.

Change-Id: I3eafc92ba7c7305b1a73d3f96c427ed12c96dbf7
(cherry picked from commit a962943bdaa746ad238f003f56556eb02d1ea8e8)

messages:

Use TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE

UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE is old name and deprecated
This allows to use upper-constraints file as more
readable way instead of UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE=<lower-constraints file>.

commit_message:
Update requirements and lower-constraints

Bring the versions specified in requirements.txt and test-req.txt
closer to what's actually being used in the py36 and py38 testenvs,
and update lower-constraints to reflect the updated requirements.

What has made this necessary right now is that the latest pip has
introduced a much stricter resolver, and the oslo lower-constraints
job is failing because oslo is imposing some constraints which are
too low for some dependencies, and we can't get away with that under
the stricter resolver.

Change-Id: I4d9544f0b49a0fe47709e2693279119ea31ea155

commit_message:
drop mock from lower-constraints

The mock third party library was needed for mock support in py2
runtimes. Since we now only support py36 and later, we don't need it
in lower-constraints.

These changes will help us to drop `mock` from openstack/requirements

Change-Id: I49eeb9819bc49b73f3d58e700e46dfe0f6e7ae83

commit_message:
Fix the bandit version.

To fix:

ERROR: Could not find a version that satisfies the requirement bandit<1.7.0,>=1.6.0
ERROR: No matching distribution found for bandit<1.7.0,>=1.6.0

Fix the version of bandit in the lower-constraints.txt file to match
with the version in the test-requirements.txt file.

Change-Id: Ieaba9e58ca7f96e84f27ff7bf07684ec4c5f2631

subject: Use --ignore-times when transferring files via rsync
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 6816, 'name': 'Jesse Pretorius', 'email': 'jesse@odyssey4.me', 'username': 'jesse-pretorius'}, {'_account_id': 6926, 'name': 'Bogdan Dobrelya', 'email': 'bdobreli@redhat.com', 'username': 'bogdando'}, {'_account_id': 20172, 'name': 'Michele Baldessari', 'email': 'michele@acksyn.org', 'username': 'michele'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23181, 'name': 'RDO Third Party CI', 'email': 'dmsimard+rdothirdparty@redhat.com', 'username': 'rdothirdparty', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages: [{'account_id': 20172, 'date': '2021-04-14 19:59:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 20172, 'date': '2021-04-14 20:00:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 20172, 'date': '2021-04-15 06:27:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 20172, 'date': '2021-04-15 06:28:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 20172, 'date': '2021-04-15 13:37:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2021-04-15 13:42:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2021-04-15 15:04:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 20172, 'date': '2021-04-16 06:23:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-04-14 19:59:03.000000000', 'message': 'Use --checksum when transferring files via rsync

Currently rsync is being called without passing --checksum. So any file
that has the same size/permission and *timestamp* will not be
transferred over. Now *timestamp* in this case means 1 second
resolution. See also the following rsync option which explains it:

  --modify-window=NUM, -@ When comparing two timestamps, rsync treats the
    timestamps as being equal if they differ by no more than the
    modify-window value. The default is 0, which matches just integer
    seconds.

This has shown to be problematic at the very least with the mariadb
system transfer where only a partial list of files would be transferred,
causing all kinds of data corruption and segfaults in the database being
leapped.

Closes-Bug: #1923898

Change-Id: Ibd53fad900cfa002bf2ad9b2ae6f62babd4140e5
Co-Authored-By: Damien Ciabrini <dciabrin@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-By: John Eckersberg <jeckersb@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 46acaa92ced8d05ed56c18ee4bc2d4a37f640cea)
'}, {'created': '2021-04-15 06:27:31.000000000', 'message': 'Use --ignore-times when transferring files via rsync

Currently rsync is being called without passing --ignore-times nor
--checksum. So any file that has the same size/permission and
*timestamp* will not be transferred over. Now *timestamp* in this case
means 1 second resolution. See also the following rsync option which
explains it:

  --modify-window=NUM, -@ When comparing two timestamps, rsync treats the
    timestamps as being equal if they differ by no more than the
    modify-window value. The default is 0, which matches just integer
    seconds.

This has shown to be problematic at the very least with the mariadb
system transfer where only a partial list of files would be transferred,
causing all kinds of data corruption and segfaults in the database being
leapped.

We debated the use of --checksum vs --ignore-times and are settling on
--ignore-times to avoid any risks of hash collision (and hence missed
transfer of a different file, since the default hash is 128bits)
and because that is also what the galera SST helper uses and has proven
solid over time, so it seems the more cautious decision.

Closes-Bug: #1923898

Change-Id: Ibd53fad900cfa002bf2ad9b2ae6f62babd4140e5

commit_message:
Use --ignore-times when transferring files via rsync

Currently rsync is being called without passing --ignore-times nor
--checksum. So any file that has the same size/permission and
*timestamp* will not be transferred over. Now *timestamp* in this case
means 1 second resolution. See also the following rsync option which
explains it:

  --modify-window=NUM, -@ When comparing two timestamps, rsync treats the
    timestamps as being equal if they differ by no more than the
    modify-window value. The default is 0, which matches just integer
    seconds.

This has shown to be problematic at the very least with the mariadb
system transfer where only a partial list of files would be transferred,
causing all kinds of data corruption and segfaults in the database being
leapped.

We debated the use of --checksum vs --ignore-times and are settling on
--ignore-times to avoid any risks of hash collision (and hence missed
transfer of a different file, since the default hash is 128bits)
and because that is also what the galera SST helper uses and has proven
solid over time, so it seems the more cautious decision.

Closes-Bug: #1923898

Change-Id: Ibd53fad900cfa002bf2ad9b2ae6f62babd4140e5
Co-Authored-By: Damien Ciabrini <dciabrin@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-By: John Eckersberg <jeckersb@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 7ada6e1f19d6ad3b68c3451cbf42dc3243a0feb2)

Use --ignore-times when transferring files via rsync

Currently rsync is being called without passing --ignore-times nor
--checksum. So any file that has the same size/permission and
*timestamp* will not be transferred over. Now *timestamp* in this case
means 1 second resolution. See also the following rsync option which
explains it:

  --modify-window=NUM, -@ When comparing two timestamps, rsync treats the

    modify-window value. The default is 0, which matches just integer
    seconds.

This has shown to be problematic at the very least with the mariadb
system transfer where only a partial list of files would be transferred,
causing all kinds of data corruption and segfaults in the database being
leapped.

We debated the use of --checksum vs --ignore-times and are settling on
--ignore-times to avoid any risks of hash collision (and hence missed
transfer of a different file, since the default hash is 128bits)
and because that is also what the galera SST helper uses and has proven
solid over time, so it seems the more cautious decision.

subject: Use --ignore-times when transferring files via rsync
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 6816, 'name': 'Jesse Pretorius', 'email': 'jesse@odyssey4.me', 'username': 'jesse-pretorius'}, {'_account_id': 6926, 'name': 'Bogdan Dobrelya', 'email': 'bdobreli@redhat.com', 'username': 'bogdando'}, {'_account_id': 20172, 'name': 'Michele Baldessari', 'email': 'michele@acksyn.org', 'username': 'michele'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23181, 'name': 'RDO Third Party CI', 'email': 'dmsimard+rdothirdparty@redhat.com', 'username': 'rdothirdparty', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages: [{'account_id': 20172, 'date': '2021-04-15 13:30:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2021-04-15 13:42:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2021-04-15 15:04:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 20172, 'date': '2021-04-16 05:14:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-04-15 13:30:14.000000000', 'message': 'Use --ignore-times when transferring files via rsync

Currently rsync is being called without passing --ignore-times nor
--checksum. So any file that has the same size/permission and
*timestamp* will not be transferred over. Now *timestamp* in this case
means 1 second resolution. See also the following rsync option which
explains it:

  --modify-window=NUM, -@ When comparing two timestamps, rsync treats the
    timestamps as being equal if they differ by no more than the
    modify-window value. The default is 0, which matches just integer
    seconds.

This has shown to be problematic at the very least with the mariadb
system transfer where only a partial list of files would be transferred,
causing all kinds of data corruption and segfaults in the database being
leapped.

We debated the use of --checksum vs --ignore-times and are settling on
--ignore-times to avoid any risks of hash collision (and hence missed
transfer of a different file, since the default hash is 128bits)
and because that is also what the galera SST helper uses and has proven
solid over time, so it seems the more cautious decision.

Closes-Bug: #1923898

Change-Id: Ibd53fad900cfa002bf2ad9b2ae6f62babd4140e5
Co-Authored-By: Damien Ciabrini <dciabrin@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-By: John Eckersberg <jeckersb@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Use --ignore-times when transferring files via rsync

Currently rsync is being called without passing --ignore-times nor
--checksum. So any file that has the same size/permission and
*timestamp* will not be transferred over. Now *timestamp* in this case
means 1 second resolution. See also the following rsync option which
explains it:

  --modify-window=NUM, -@ When comparing two timestamps, rsync treats the
    timestamps as being equal if they differ by no more than the
    modify-window value. The default is 0, which matches just integer
    seconds.

This has shown to be problematic at the very least with the mariadb
system transfer where only a partial list of files would be transferred,
causing all kinds of data corruption and segfaults in the database being
leapped.

We debated the use of --checksum vs --ignore-times and are settling on
--ignore-times to avoid any risks of hash collision (and hence missed
transfer of a different file, since the default hash is 128bits)
and because that is also what the galera SST helper uses and has proven
solid over time, so it seems the more cautious decision.

Closes-Bug: #1923898

Change-Id: Ibd53fad900cfa002bf2ad9b2ae6f62babd4140e5
Co-Authored-By: Damien Ciabrini <dciabrin@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-By: John Eckersberg <jeckersb@redhat.com>

[{'created': '2021-03-22 16:36:44.000000000', 'message': "Disabling LM PostCopy and AutoConverge for RT roles

It's not recommended to have NovaLiveMigrationPermitPostCopy and
NovaLiveMigrationPermitAutoConverge enabled for realtime roles.

Disabling them by default.

Change-Id: I11584e5cf12bf654dd4e909dc50555003c576d1a
"}, {'created': '2021-03-22 17:01:55.000000000', 'message': "Disabling LM PostCopy and AutoConverge for RT roles

It's not recommended to have NovaLiveMigrationPermitPostCopy and
NovaLiveMigrationPermitAutoConverge enabled for realtime roles.

Change-Id: I11584e5cf12bf654dd4e909dc50555003c576d1a
"}]
commit_message:
Disabling LM PostCopy and AutoConverge for RT roles

It's not recommended to have NovaLiveMigrationPermitPostCopy and
NovaLiveMigrationPermitAutoConverge enabled for realtime roles.

Change-Id: I11584e5cf12bf654dd4e909dc50555003c576d1a

commit_message:
Read default cirros version from stackrc

Workaround for grenade jobs to read CIRROS_VERSION variable from
stackrc.
We also give the possibility to specify a custom CIRROS_VERSION

Change-Id: I118808150754f848af2fe57f750885c284655006

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-01-15 09:20:58.000000000', 'message': 'Revert "remove py37"

Reason for revert: Python 3.7 *is* supported because it falls
in the range of supported Python versions (3.6-3.8).

Change-Id: I7365634864f09eb04a68d901ca4ca962fa4d7bb2
'}]
commit_message:
Revert "remove py37"

Reason for revert: Python 3.7 *is* supported because it falls
in the range of supported Python versions (3.6-3.8).

Change-Id: I7365634864f09eb04a68d901ca4ca962fa4d7bb2

commit_message:
Add support for nova_api_{metadata_,}uwsgi_config in Debian

This patch is adding the configuration of the number of workers,
threads, and the size of the listen queue in Debian, which uses
uwsgi to run Nova API and api-metadata. Therefore, this patch adds
two new nova_api_uwsgi_config and nova_api_metadata_uwsgi_config
providers as well as two new nova::wsgi::uwsgi_api and
nova::wsgi::uwsgi_api_metadata classes.

Change-Id: Idd141edc5cddcfd79cf23e2041dbd1ce6a8252a8

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-04-07 15:09:02.000000000', 'message': 'Fix image/tasks API for in-progress tasks

A slight error in the tasks_get_by_image() DB API method resulted in
our excluding in-progress tasks from the returned list. This is
because those tasks have expires_at=NULL, and we were comparing
the expires_at>=$NOW to find unexpired tasks. This makes us check for
"NULL or not expired" instead.

We did have a test asserting the wrong behavior, but it was done to
increase coverage and thus was asserting the behavior of the code and
not the *desired* behavior. This fixes that as well.

Change-Id: I1b6971888673b64ef60bed8fbcc97bbcbcf5c2ac
'}, {'created': '2021-04-07 15:09:30.000000000', 'message': 'Fix image/tasks API for in-progress tasks

A slight error in the tasks_get_by_image() DB API method resulted in
our excluding in-progress tasks from the returned list. This is
because those tasks have expires_at=NULL, and we were comparing
the expires_at>=$NOW to find unexpired tasks. This makes us check for
"NULL or not expired" instead.

We did have a test asserting the wrong behavior, but it was done to
increase coverage and thus was asserting the behavior of the code and
not the *desired* behavior. This fixes that as well.

Closes-Bug: #1922928
Change-Id: I1b6971888673b64ef60bed8fbcc97bbcbcf5c2ac
'}]
commit_message:
Fix image/tasks API for in-progress tasks

A slight error in the tasks_get_by_image() DB API method resulted in
our excluding in-progress tasks from the returned list. This is
because those tasks have expires_at=NULL, and we were comparing
the expires_at>=$NOW to find unexpired tasks. This makes us check for
"NULL or not expired" instead.

We did have a test asserting the wrong behavior, but it was done to
increase coverage and thus was asserting the behavior of the code and
not the *desired* behavior. This fixes that as well.

Closes-Bug: #1922928
Change-Id: I1b6971888673b64ef60bed8fbcc97bbcbcf5c2ac

commit_message:
Check there are no min BW QoS in "BaseOVSTestCase"

This patche adds a check in "BaseOVSTestCase" setUp method. Each
time a test is executed, the test case checks there are no
minimum bandwidth QoS/queues related to this OVS instance. The OVS
instance generates a random "_min_bw_qos_id" in the initialization.
This ID is assigned to the OVS QoS registers, in "external_ids:id".

Related-Bug: #1922919

Change-Id: I6955aadc51bfc9181ec84f7d54a219ffa3fd9115

commit_message:
Add Python3 xena unit tests

This is an automatically generated patch to ensure unit testing
is in place for all the of the tested runtimes for xena.

See also the PTI in governance [1].

[1]: https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/project-testing-interface.html

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-04-14 19:51:27.000000000', 'message': 'Use --checksum when transferring files via rsync

Currently rsync is being called without passing --checksum. So any file
that has the same size/permission and *timestamp* will not be
transferred over. Now *timestamp* in this case means 1 second
resolution. See also the following rsync option which explains it:

  --modify-window=NUM, -@ When comparing two timestamps, rsync treats the
    timestamps as being equal if they differ by no more than the
    modify-window value. The default is 0, which matches just integer
    seconds.

This has shown to be problematic at the very least with the mariadb
system transfer where only a partial list of files would be transferred,
causing all kinds of data corruption and segfaults in the database being
leapped.

Closes-Bug: #1923898

Change-Id: Ibd53fad900cfa002bf2ad9b2ae6f62babd4140e5
Co-Authored-By: Damien Ciabrini <dciabrin@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-By: John Eckersberg <jeckersb@redhat.com>
'}, {'created': '2021-04-15 06:26:46.000000000', 'message': 'Use --ignore-times when transferring files via rsync

Currently rsync is being called without passing --ignore-times nor
--checksum. So any file that has the same size/permission and
*timestamp* will not be transferred over. Now *timestamp* in this case
means 1 second resolution. See also the following rsync option which
explains it:

  --modify-window=NUM, -@ When comparing two timestamps, rsync treats the
    timestamps as being equal if they differ by no more than the
    modify-window value. The default is 0, which matches just integer
    seconds.

This has shown to be problematic at the very least with the mariadb
system transfer where only a partial list of files would be transferred,
causing all kinds of data corruption and segfaults in the database being
leapped.

We debated the use of --checksum vs --ignore-times and are settling on
--ignore-times to avoid any risks of hash collision (and hence missed
transfer of a different file, since the default hash is 128bits)
and because that is also what the galera SST helper uses and has proven
solid over time, so it seems the more cautious decision.

Closes-Bug: #1923898

Change-Id: Ibd53fad900cfa002bf2ad9b2ae6f62babd4140e5
Co-Authored-By: Damien Ciabrini <dciabrin@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-By: John Eckersberg <jeckersb@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Use --ignore-times when transferring files via rsync

Currently rsync is being called without passing --ignore-times nor
--checksum. So any file that has the same size/permission and
*timestamp* will not be transferred over. Now *timestamp* in this case
means 1 second resolution. See also the following rsync option which
explains it:

  --modify-window=NUM, -@ When comparing two timestamps, rsync treats the
    timestamps as being equal if they differ by no more than the
    modify-window value. The default is 0, which matches just integer
    seconds.

This has shown to be problematic at the very least with the mariadb
system transfer where only a partial list of files would be transferred,
causing all kinds of data corruption and segfaults in the database being
leapped.

We debated the use of --checksum vs --ignore-times and are settling on
--ignore-times to avoid any risks of hash collision (and hence missed
transfer of a different file, since the default hash is 128bits)
and because that is also what the galera SST helper uses and has proven
solid over time, so it seems the more cautious decision.

Closes-Bug: #1923898

Change-Id: Ibd53fad900cfa002bf2ad9b2ae6f62babd4140e5
Co-Authored-By: Damien Ciabrini <dciabrin@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-By: John Eckersberg <jeckersb@redhat.com>

commit_message:
[CI] Enable debugging iptables rule in the L3 agent

It should helps us understand why in some (rare) cases rule to redirect
packets send 169.254.169.254:80 to port 9697 isn't installed in the
qrouter namespace.

Change-Id: I644ea3d6767db36bfe7f4122ec2c2afe9888dd07
Related-Bug: #1920778

commit_message:
Update min supported service version for Xena.

Nova only supports compute services that are not older than version
N-1. So in Xena the smallest supported nova compute version is Wallaby
and the smallest Wallaby service version is 54.

Change-Id: I58cbac1ff087f7fd465997d06c2db7079086eb82

commit_message:
Move gawk into general for post-config

Devstack script for setting post-config needs gawk.
So this patch moves gawk from files/*/nova into files/*/general.

Closes-Bug: #1909041
Change-Id: I06a1a5524f146a8d7337963e846b5a6b7561be13

commit_message:
Refactor Ceph OSD Init Scripts - First PS

This is the first of multiple updates to ceph-osd where the OSD
init code will be refactored for better sustainability.

This patchset makes 2 changes:

1) Removes "ceph-disk" support, as ceph-disk was removed from the
   ceph image since nautilus.
2) Separates the initialization code for the bluestore, filestore,
   and directory backend configuration options.

Change-Id: I116ce9cc8d3bac870adba8b84677ec652bbb0dd4

Removed hard-coded value for backendPort

This change will retrieve the backend port from values.yaml
instead of a hard-coded value.

[{'created': '2021-03-24 14:52:24.000000000', 'message': "IPMI: Handle vendor set boot device differences

Supermicro machines, when in UEFI mode, have a different
device number, in binary, to represent the hard disk from
other vendors such as Fujitsu which actually has somewhat
similar code in their driver.

This means we need to be somewhat cognizent of the vendor of
the BMC and possibly update the device mapping based upon that
vendor.

This may ultimately fix a number of IPMI related problems, because
there is a reliance upon the text output of ipmitool, which only
reads the bytes retured by the BMC, which may not be reality after
the next reset, espescialy if ipmitool doesn't know of the UEFI
operating difference.

NOTE: This had to be a direct cherry-pick from the original change
as the intermediate branch that we normally would have cherry-picked
from has had other changes made to it, which resulted in an unclean
backport, where as with the original change it was clean. This was
then backported from stable/ussuri to stable/train, where
test_ipmitool.py conflicted slightly due to later eventlet changes.

Change-Id: Ie19db9e0cf1eafdfc9bb46248f4d457337821f94
Story: 2008241
Task: 41085
(cherry picked from commit a7ac9ce8cd53fdebdf0d9aaeaf439da08a0b3ec8)
(cherry picked from commit 8bf3f47476ba685a2aa696aa413b4706f71a4f7a)

commit_message:
IPMI: Handle vendor set boot device differences

Supermicro machines, when in UEFI mode, have a different
device number, in binary, to represent the hard disk from
other vendors such as Fujitsu which actually has somewhat
similar code in their driver.

This means we need to be somewhat cognizent of the vendor of
the BMC and possibly update the device mapping based upon that
vendor.

This may ultimately fix a number of IPMI related problems, because
there is a reliance upon the text output of ipmitool, which only
reads the bytes retured by the BMC, which may not be reality after
the next reset, espescialy if ipmitool doesn't know of the UEFI
operating difference.

NOTE: This had to be a direct cherry-pick from the original change
as the intermediate branch that we normally would have cherry-picked
from has had other changes made to it, which resulted in an unclean
backport, where as with the original change it was clean. This was
then backported from stable/ussuri to stable/train, where
test_ipmitool.py conflicted slightly due to later eventlet changes.

Change-Id: Ie19db9e0cf1eafdfc9bb46248f4d457337821f94
Story: 2008241
Task: 41085
(cherry picked from commit a7ac9ce8cd53fdebdf0d9aaeaf439da08a0b3ec8)
(cherry picked from commit 8bf3f47476ba685a2aa696aa413b4706f71a4f7a)

commit_message:
Remove the stable branch jobs from stable/wallaby gate

devstack-plugin-ceph is now branched, and each branch
will maintain the respective branch specific code and
testing.

Any job running on wallaby gate will be against the stable/wallaby
OpenStack. This also removes the stable branch specific-jobs definition.

Change-Id: Idc2f00e86afe2cfbbe126da08851683adc5b57ad

commit_message:
[Train Only] Ensure novajoin code is setting ansible_fqdn

Novajoin tls-e code is still available in train and is affected by
the same removal of the fact passing as [1].  This uses
ansible_facts['fqdn'] as the ansible_fqdn for the tripleo-ipa
registration play.

[1]: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/785909

Related-Bug: 1915761
Related-Bug: 1923248
Change-Id: I5b1514b4ba9bb22bcef63e74b0400cd9332516ca

commit_message:
Ensure ansible_fqdn is set

The ipaclient ansible role requires that ansible_fqdn is defined but
due to [1] we don't have ansible_fqdn inside of ansible_facts.  This
uses the 'fqdn' ansible fact for ansible_fqdn which is equivalent.

[1]: https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/4e79336d69e
6b7fa4b026922bac7953bafeee96d

Related-Bug: 1915761
Closes-Bug: 1923248
Change-Id: I0a740e86588c96fff24fa09698c35e492d1c64db

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/wallaby

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/wallaby branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I2b34b7d28513a9f47d6210fbca59d3a6ee68ffd9

[{'created': '2021-04-15 14:15:05.000000000', 'message': "Move flake8 as a pre-commit local target.

The goal here is to avoid conflicts between flake8 and hacking version
each 2 days.

The flake8 version to install will be determined by hacking and

versions.

[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/hacking/src/branch/master/requirements.txt#L1

"}]
commit_message:
Move flake8 as a pre-commit local target.

The goal here is to avoid conflicts between flake8 and hacking version
each 2 days.

Inspired from nova's approach [1].

The flake8 version to install will be determined by hacking and
requirements [2] will stay aligned instead of relying on different
versions.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/src/branch/master/.pre-commit-config.yaml#L26-L35
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/hacking/src/branch/master/requirements.txt#L1

Change-Id: I09f9371f08064a6897d6be027597827e2bc3c166
(cherry picked from commit b1528f9cabc19bf615d950213de0e6514b9f4121)

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/wallaby

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/wallaby branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I9bcb94dae06117ab81f4c07a6efa6862ee177711

commit_message:
Move flake8 as a pre-commit local target.

The goal here is to avoid conflicts between flake8 and hacking version
each 2 days.

Inspired from nova's approach [1].

The flake8 version to install will be determined by hacking and
requirements [2] will stay aligned instead of relying on different
versions.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/src/branch/master/.pre-commit-config.yaml#L26-L35
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/hacking/src/branch/master/requirements.txt#L1

Change-Id: I668a7489b215adb89f301de65159ad442cdb7718
(cherry picked from commit ceca2bbd5db1525430703647acaff89c5f50061f)
