commit_message:
Add support for neutron_api_uwsgi_config in Debian

This patch is adding the configuration of the number of workers,
threads, and the size of the listen queue in Debian, which uses
uwsgi to run Neutron API. Therefore, this patch adds a new
neutron_api_uwsgi_config provider as well as a new
neutron::wsgi::uwsgi class.

Change-Id: Iaa4171c05586ddca9fd3af1b4a78adfbe4105bab

subject: [OVN] Remove check for OVN + Availability Zones
messages: [{'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2021-03-30 08:16:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 7144, 'date': '2021-04-12 20:19:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 11082, 'date': '2021-04-14 17:40:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2021-04-15 09:05:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:\n\nrecheck'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-03-30 08:16:12.000000000', 'message': '[OVN] Remove check for OVN + Availability Zones

The ML2/OVN driver does support AZ-aware routing scheduling from
stable/train and newer versions.

This patch also removes the check from the DHCP agent container because
although not a typical deployment, the Neutron DHCP agent can be
deployed with OVN for special cases such as baremetal provisioning where
the agent would serve DHCP to the baremetal instances.

Change-Id: I8941c4d9a8e68eb775c910495de4aff9fbc67206
Signed-off-by: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com>
(cherry picked from commit 9283e44d16214f148e04a66d248514b170dad07f)
'}]
commit_message:
[OVN] Remove check for OVN + Availability Zones

The ML2/OVN driver does support AZ-aware routing scheduling from
stable/train and newer versions.

This patch also removes the check from the DHCP agent container because
although not a typical deployment, the Neutron DHCP agent can be
deployed with OVN for special cases such as baremetal provisioning where
the agent would serve DHCP to the baremetal instances.

Change-Id: I8941c4d9a8e68eb775c910495de4aff9fbc67206
Signed-off-by: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com>
(cherry picked from commit 9283e44d16214f148e04a66d248514b170dad07f)

commit_message:
Use ansible_facts in tripleo_ssh_known_hosts role

It was missed in original patch to switch to
ansible_facts[1].

For providing test value for 'ssh_host_key_rsa_public' overriding
it in 'ansible_facts' with set_fact.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-ansible/+/776666

Closes-Bug: #1923403
Related-Bug: #1915761
Change-Id: I9d5ae576c57eefe5496f9dda71e8eac23e45e89f
(cherry picked from commit 30df6f54375bb3ffa0cdd40ca219905b2fa92cf5)
(cherry picked from commit b52dc1e7fd69fdc360f1281c53ac92abb7dddfee)

commit_message:
Use ansible_facts in tripleo_ssh_known_hosts role

It was missed in original patch to switch to
ansible_facts[1].

For providing test value for 'ssh_host_key_rsa_public' overriding
it in 'ansible_facts' with set_fact.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-ansible/+/776666

Closes-Bug: #1923403
Related-Bug: #1915761
Change-Id: I9d5ae576c57eefe5496f9dda71e8eac23e45e89f
(cherry picked from commit 30df6f54375bb3ffa0cdd40ca219905b2fa92cf5)

subject: Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/wallaby
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-03-19 13:13:37.000000000', 'message': 'Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/wallaby

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/wallaby branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I33254414c1ee3ae1a31a8bf8fc89864ef1494151
'}]
commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/wallaby

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/wallaby branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I33254414c1ee3ae1a31a8bf8fc89864ef1494151

commit_message:
Test dashboard only for horizon scenario

We should not run horizon tempest test for each lxc-based job. Instead
we want to run it only when we change os_horizon.

Additionally we disable SSL validation since at the moment self-signed
SSLs are not trusted.

Change-Id: Iace7c54dd19709e4cf7aebb98fd8756299390d67

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/wallaby

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/wallaby branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I0a65f8390417295038a78f1de1590b4a33470242

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/ussuri

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/ussuri branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I49e73f0c9f4d84304e13dfaa38a4f894af321ad7

commit_message:
Move flake8 as a pre-commit local target.

The goal here is to avoid conflicts between flake8 and hacking version each
2 days.

Inspired from nova's approach[1].

The flake8 version to install will be determined by hacking and
requirements[2] will stay aligned instead of relying on different versions.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/src/branch/master/.pre-commit-config.yaml#L26-L35
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/hacking/src/branch/master/requirements.txt#L1

Change-Id: Id33601ce5949950e4791052ea34a4bf4b0e02158

commit_message:
Move flake8 as a pre-commit local target.

The goal here is to avoid conflicts between flake8 and hacking version each
2 days.

Inspired from nova's approach[1].

The flake8 version to install will be determined by hacking and
requirements[2] will stay aligned instead of relying on different versions.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/src/branch/master/.pre-commit-config.yaml#L26-L35
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/hacking/src/branch/master/requirements.txt#L1

Change-Id: I7e22a1530e531185f64eef524b06b49544af407e
(cherry picked from commit ce8d61bfa2a5f33331fcde1aab81c12a9b417777)

commit_message:
Stop to use the __future__ module.

The __future__ module [1] was used in this context to ensure compatibility
between python 2 and python 3.

We previously dropped the support of python 2.7 [2] and now we only support
python 3 so we don't need to continue to use this module and the imports
listed below.

Imports commonly used and their related PEPs:
- `division` is related to PEP 238 [3]
- `print_function` is related to PEP 3105 [4]
- `unicode_literals` is related to PEP 3112 [5]
- `with_statement` is related to PEP 343 [6]
- `absolute_import` is related to PEP 328 [7]

[1] https://docs.python.org/3/library/__future__.html
[2] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html
[3] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0238
[4] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-3105
[5] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-3112
[6] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0343
[7] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0328

Change-Id: I64dc35fb8f4242b5c49e0a46397c545be5427562

subject: Remove glance-registry pod
messages:
[{'account_id': 30356, 'date': '2020-07-07 15:18:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 21420, 'date': '2020-07-07 15:30:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2

We currently still run Queens, Pike, Ocata in the periodic gates, so for the time being we still need to hang on to glance registry.

There may be deployments as well on the current maintained releases that utilize glance registry (although I hope not), and this would most likely break them.

We need to look at removing those older releases from the current checks, once we do that, then we can remove this.'}, {'account_id': 21420, 'date': '2021-04-15 19:21:45.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

Abandoning since there hasn't been any recent activity, if anyone wants to continue this work, please feel free to restore this or create a new change."}]

If ingress-vip is used in keepalived mode, the security_context variable is not applied, so the ingress-vip container is not executed.

'}]
commit_message:
Add security_context for keepalived

If ingress-vip is used in keepalived mode, the security_context variable is not applied, so the ingress-vip container is not executed.
So, modify deployment-ingress.yaml to apply security_context variable.

https://storyboard.openstack.org/#!/story/2007788

Change-Id: I59483660b029660038557b61d7cca264a7dc2d43

commit_message:
Enable tty and stdin for containers in debug mode

With this commit by setting 'debug: true' in values, containers allocate
tty and stdin buffer, allowing to attach to running container and
use pdb with e.g.:

kubectl attach -nopenstack glance-api

Apparently this won't work straight forward with services running under
apache2, such as keystone and horizon.

Init containers are ommitted in scope of this commit.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/722617/

Change-Id: I5b609ef9105020508f5c070e5b3a0dbd9f631e99

commit_message:
Update master for stable/wallaby

Add file to the reno documentation build to show release notes for
stable/wallaby.

Use pbr instruction to increment the minor version number
automatically so that master versions are higher than the versions on
stable/wallaby.

Sem-Ver: feature
Change-Id: I29d90fbf1a417053b1a50b0f70a6f61804346eb1

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/wallaby

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/wallaby branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I574fc05aa6db53e10920d2594f7f6c9b679236fd

commit_message:
Schedule ironic compute to openstack-control-plane node

The patch changes default label for ironic compute to openstack-control-plane=enabled.
Since nova-compute with ironic virt driver is stateless deployment that might be running
in cloud without Qemu computes.

Change-Id: I6e06d74d8bb89c730b078f791dbb506e7bd0ab99

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-26 12:16:27.000000000', 'message': 'Map pipped to sha256 does not provide same output on successive executions

Maps in GO are not sorted, to solve this we need to pipe the output
through a function that orders the content.

One such function is toJson which calls json.Marshal, a function that
encodes maps to JSON and provides a sorted output as described here:
https://golang.org/pkg/encoding/json/#Marshal

For more details on the impact see the storyboard description.

Change-Id: I1d5fe3ea2d3b79b80b87d143d5f762f7c64a1a40
Task: 2006278
Signed-off-by: Ovidiu Poncea <ovidiu.poncea@windriver.com>

commit_message:
Map pipped to sha256 does not provide same output on successive executions

Maps in GO are not sorted, to solve this we need to pipe the output
through a function that orders the content.

One such function is toJson which calls json.Marshal, a function that
encodes maps to JSON and provides a sorted output as described here:
https://golang.org/pkg/encoding/json/#Marshal

For more details on the impact see the storyboard description.

Change-Id: I1d5fe3ea2d3b79b80b87d143d5f762f7c64a1a40
Task: 35979
Signed-off-by: Ovidiu Poncea <ovidiu.poncea@windriver.com>

subject: Add support for tap-as-a-service plugin
messages:
[{'account_id': 27589, 'date': '2020-06-01 04:34:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 17305, 'date': '2020-06-05 03:43:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 20466, 'date': '2020-06-05 13:18:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 21420, 'date': '2020-06-05 16:33:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 8863, 'date': '2020-06-12 21:28:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I don't think this is the right approach. You may want to reuse native loci functionality to add required software you your existing images. E.g. to include taas to an image you just do:
docker build . --build-arg PROJECT=tap-as-a-service --build-arg PROJECT_REPO=https://opendev.org/x/tap-as-a-service --build-arg PLUGIN=neutron --build-arg FROM=openstackhelm/neutron:stein-ubuntu_bionic --build-arg WHEELS=/opt/loci/wheels.tar --build-arg PYTHON3=yes
(add profiles, dist and pip packages if you need on top)

This functionality is currently slightly flawed for your case, but issue will be addressed here:
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/735394

To have it included to neutron-sriov image you'll need to implement it as a job and have 2 stage build.
Please reach me if you need more details."}, {'account_id': 21420, 'date': '2021-04-15 19:14:15.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

Abandoning since there hasn't been any recent activity, if anyone wants to continue this work, please feel free to restore this or create a new change."}]

[{'created': '2020-06-01 04:34:53.000000000', 'message': 'Add support for tap-as-a-service plugin

Add tap-as-a-service plugin and custom python-neutronclient to
neutron and heat loci images.

Change-Id: I6141712139161a38d16a89ab1ef56009f8635049
'}]
commit_message:
Add support for tap-as-a-service plugin

Add tap-as-a-service plugin and custom python-neutronclient to
neutron and heat loci images.

Change-Id: I6141712139161a38d16a89ab1ef56009f8635049

commit_message:
Switch etcd to staetefulset

* Add support to store date on PVC
* Allow to deploy in cluster mode
* The scale-up/scale down operations are not supported and will be
  implemented in further patches.

Change-Id: If1b605d6e72fa45362dfc6b2ca4b4e8f820eb0cb

commit_message:
Switch API services for http probes

Use HTTP probes instead of TCP for API services.
Still use TCP for placement as it returns 401 on old releases.

Change-Id: I6a1d9aacf27615fec77aa201db515f5be7b23f41

commit_message:
Add support for glance_api_uwsgi_config in Debian

This patch is adding the configuration of the number of workers,
threads, and the size of the listen queue in Debian, which uses
uwsgi to run Glance API. Therefore, this patch adds a new
glance_api_uwsgi_config provider as well as a new
glance::wsgi::uwsgi class.

Change-Id: If02def38d583f2255b8a0219dc53c26f0980521c

commit_message:
[Mariadb] Move to HAProxy

The PS replaces Nginx Ingress controller by HAProxy for Mariadb chart.
Current implementation of Nginx Ingress Controller does not allow to use
active-backup algorithm. The PS solves this issue.

Change-Id: I3d9076a93e0725c1cf74acef189f50d010a4dddb

commit_message:
[Neutron] Drop dependency to nova compute

For unknown reason some neutron resources have dependencies
to nova compute. The patch drops them to allow installing
neutron prior to nova service.
The dependency still present for neutron-metadata agent and
tests job.

Change-Id: Iada614a46afd99a9524feeec3f266d354c7779ce
Related-Prod: PRODX-1649

subject: Adds nvme device support to ceph-osd
messages:
[{'account_id': 31468, 'date': '2020-01-02 03:20:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2020-01-02 03:20:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2020-01-15 01:01:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Thanks and welcome to the OpenStack community. I am adding few core member of the help infra team to review this change and help you accordingly. 

Feel free to contract FC SIG for any further help on OpenStack contribution. - https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/First_Contact_SIG'}, {'account_id': 21420, 'date': '2021-04-15 19:01:58.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

Abandoning since there hasn't been any recent activity, if anyone wants to continue this work, please feel free to restore this or create a new change."}]

[{'created': '2021-02-21 01:58:21.000000000', 'message': 'Update tests for scoped tokens and default roles

This patch refactors the RBAC enforcement checks in the API tests.
It also updates those test for keystone scoped tokens and default roles.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/devstack/+/774524

commit_message:
Update tests for scoped tokens and default roles

This patch refactors the RBAC enforcement checks in the API tests.
It also updates those test for keystone scoped tokens and default roles.

Change-Id: I6fad03f5a89c213562918ca258884aac34ba7ce7

LGMT, but the conflict must be fixed'}, {'account_id': 26441, 'date': '2018-05-07 15:49:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 8898, 'date': '2018-05-07 15:53:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

how robust and well tested is all this?

shell is notoriously fragile and we have a lot of echo / sed and what not going on which by inspection of the patch is hard to convince myself is right or wrong'}, {'account_id': 26441, 'date': '2018-05-07 15:58:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

It's fairly heavily tested at this point — we've been using this patch with very few changes for several months over a variety of versions of the base ceph charts.

While it's true there's a good bit of scripting here, what it's doing is pretty simple: just resolve the link (either out of /sys/bus/scsi or /dev/disk/by-path) to a logical device name."}, {'account_id': 26441, 'date': '2018-05-07 16:10:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Published edit on patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 26441, 'date': '2018-05-07 16:46:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Published edit on patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 21691, 'date': '2018-05-08 11:36:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 14151, 'date': '2018-05-13 04:41:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 23928, 'date': '2018-05-13 04:52:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Patch Set 7 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 26441, 'date': '2018-05-13 15:24:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: Code-Review+1

> how robust and well tested is all this?
 > 
 > shell is notoriously fragile and we have a lot of echo / sed and
 > what not going on which by inspection of the patch is hard to
 > convince myself is right or wrong

One _very_ late note on the testing, by the way: proper gate tests for this patch require the loopback device patch ( https://review.openstack.org/#/c/539019/ ).  By the same token, properly testing _that_ patch requires _this_ patch.  So once either this patch or that one merges, we'll want to follow-up with a patch that adds the loopback-based tests.  That should be pretty straightforward as we've done exactly those tests outside the gate environment.  Just want to make sure that's ok with everyone."}, {'account_id': 28372, 'date': '2018-08-29 22:29:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Patch Set 8 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 21420, 'date': '2021-04-15 18:56:01.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

commit_message:
Ceph device naming by physical path

This change adds the ability to identify ceph OSD and journal locations by
SCSI or iSCSI path.  A new device type, 'block-bus', is added (in addition to
'directory' and 'block-logical').  SCSI devices are specified as
"scsi@bus:x.y.z".  Attached iSCSI devices are specified as
"iSCSI@ip:port:iqn:unit:lun" (iSCSI device must already be attached;
the change does not discover/attach targets.)

Change-Id: I3bf43a1c2b75bd2cdcca9dc858937f3eb68928d3

- noop http://logs.openstack.org/54/457754/1/check/noop/0ff1e06/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 20443, 'date': '2017-04-18 18:07:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 23928, 'date': '2017-04-18 19:12:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Interesting approach - would be great to get Sébastien Han's input here.

There seems to be an architectural decision we need to make here:
 * Run pod in host PID namespace and launch OSD process per device.
 * Run pod (or container in pod) with single OSD process for each device.

It seems that the former is more flexible in that is's easier to accommodate varying hardware and devices, but the latter cleaner in deployment."}, {'account_id': 6984, 'date': '2017-04-18 22:51:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

That's should work, I'm just wondering if we couldn't do this in 2 steps. Like one step with a privileged container to prepare it and then another non-privileged accessing the device with something similar to docker command run --device just for the activate sequence."}, {'account_id': 7769, 'date': '2017-04-19 15:51:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 7769, 'date': '2017-04-19 16:00:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 7769, 'date': '2017-04-19 16:03:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Interesting approach - would be great to get Sébastien Han's input
 > here.
 > 
 > There seems to be an architectural decision we need to make here:
 > * Run pod in host PID namespace and launch OSD process per device.
 > * Run pod (or container in pod) with single OSD process for each
 > device.
 > 
 > It seems that the former is more flexible in that is's easier to
 > accommodate varying hardware and devices, but the latter cleaner in
 > deployment.

The response to this should really come from Sebastien.  There is value to having these self-contained and isolated, and each osd process in its own pod.  I am not sure that I think flexibility with regard to devices can only come from a host PID mega-osd-spawner--an init container in front of each osd pod with some state could serve the same purpose.  I am always inclined to lean toward one process per container to allow k8s to do its job of process management and have that bubble up a generic chain to whatever is watching.  A mega-pod would require supervisor, custom osd process monitoring, restarting, bubbling up of issues, and so on."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2017-04-23 00:41:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified-1

Merge Failed.

Guys, do you mind sharing thoughts on that approach? https://github.com/ceph/ceph-docker/pull/610

This could help us moving forward with this I guess.

Pete, Larry -- what happened to SCSI ID targeting as discussed?'}, {'account_id': 20443, 'date': '2017-07-27 14:18:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 18:

Pete has a PS to add a loopback device and assign it a scsi ID, once that is merged in I can use that approach for getting this PS running in the gate by scsi ID'}, {'account_id': 20443, 'date': '2017-07-27 14:18:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 18: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 26441, 'date': '2017-07-27 14:33:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 18:

> Pete has a PS to add a loopback device and assign it a scsi ID,
 > once that is merged in I can use that approach for getting this PS
 > running in the gate by scsi ID

don't want to step on Pete's plan for this, but what form do we want the SCSI IDs to take?  As a suggestion, if we go with something like like {pci-loc}-{scsiloc}, it'd be dead trivial to transform that into a path into /dev/disk/by-path; that'd make supporting this virtually identical to supporting disks by name.

just a thought."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2017-07-30 05:58:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 18: Verified-1

Is there a problem with allowing hostname to be configured on a per-OSD basis?'}, {'account_id': 26509, 'date': '2017-08-08 13:53:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 24:

HOSTNAME is only used in osd_directory.sh, per https://github.com/ceph/ceph-docker/blob/master/ceph-releases/luminous/ubuntu/16.04/daemon/osd_scenarios/osd_directory.sh'}, {'account_id': 26201, 'date': '2017-08-08 13:58:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 24:

Build Failed 

http://10.24.20.18:30081/job/community-singlenode/job/osh-singlenode/69/ : FAILURE (skipped)'}, {'account_id': 26441, 'date': '2017-08-08 14:02:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 24:

I'm not sure that's relevant.  The reason for my suggested change is that you might want to configure the hostname differently if you've got multiple OSDs on a single host; for example: if some of your OSDs are hosted on a external array but mounted across hosts, for failure-domain reasons it might be a good idea to give all those OSDs the same hostname, as opposed to using the nodenames."}, {'account_id': 26509, 'date': '2017-08-08 14:16:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 24:

Wouldn't having the same hostname but on different nodes confuse the crush map?"}, {'account_id': 26441, 'date': '2017-08-08 14:20:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 24:

the idea is that you build your crushmap with the hostnames you assign to the OSDs; this way you can exercise control via crush and osd hostnames over where objects land.

my understanding, by the way, is that this can be configured on a per-osd basis in ceph.conf as well, which is part of the reason i favor this change.  most people wouldn't use it, but it seems like a nice tool to have in a world where you have a mix of host and array storage."}, {'account_id': 26509, 'date': '2017-08-08 14:22:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 24:

Sure, more flexibility is a good idea to me. Sorry not getting it earlier. Please add it back.'}, {'account_id': 26441, 'date': '2017-08-08 14:31:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 25: Published edit on patch set 24'}, {'account_id': 26201, 'date': '2017-08-08 14:31:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 25:

change 38: Per discussion with rootfs, journal activation was not happening at all; for device journals this is necessary.  with the change to osd_activate_journal.sh to only act on block devices, it should be safe to unconditionally call it regardless of the actual block device.  so we just activate the journal whenever we activate a disk.

this does NOT currently handle the case where you've got a device journal but a directory OSD, and it may result in journals being activated multiple times if something actually starts invoking entrypoint.sh with CEPH_DAEMON set to "osd_activate_journal".'}, {'account_id': 26201, 'date': '2017-08-29 19:29:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 38:

Any suggestions?'}, {'account_id': 26441, 'date': '2017-12-01 00:13:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 91:

I get the same thing.  

The build failures seem to point to some kind of environmental issue.  The zuul logs show this for non-primary ubuntu nodes:

container_linux.go:247: starting container process caused "process_linux.go:359: container init caused "rootfs_linux.go:54: mounting "/dev/shm" to rootfs "/var/lib/docker/aufs/mnt/1dfa44104b525caff3bc641e7bd3c53cb5f631ced0219b1ba67af5d32d1c7a72" at "/var/lib/docker/aufs/mnt/1dfa44104b525caff3bc641e7bd3c53cb5f631ced0219b1ba67af5d32d1c7a72/dev/shm" caused "no space left on device"""

... while the primary has this:

Warning: Identity file /etc/nodepool/id_rsa not accessible: No such file or directory.
Error: No such container: kubelet

I also note that the builds on centos and fedora just aren't happening at all.

I'm stumped.'}, {'account_id': 18476, 'date': '2017-12-01 07:23:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 91:

My local test shows this error. 
node singlevm supports OSD daemon scsi-2-0-0-0-j-scsi-3-0-0-0
+ kubectl label nodes singlevm cephosd-device-scsi-2-0-0-0-j-scsi-3-0-0-0=enabled
The connection to the server localhost:8080 was refused - did you specify the right host or port?

My systems are behind a proxy server and i am not sure if that is causing this issue. Would be nice to get hold of failure logs to see if this is similar to that.'}, {'account_id': 26441, 'date': '2017-12-01 13:49:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 91:

Likely a bug — I suspect the kubernetes admin.conf isn't in the right place when that gets called.  Will fix."}, {'account_id': 18476, 'date': '2017-12-01 15:54:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 91:

My environment is different but I have the admin.conf at the right location and the command works just fine when run right after the script fails. Mine is sitting at $HOME/.kube/config"}, {'account_id': 18476, 'date': '2017-12-01 18:18:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 91:

Apologies for the noise. The issue reported by me was something unique to my setup. I had to set KUBECONFIG in my env, without which the gate scripts sets it to $HOME/.kubeadm-aio/config (i assumed it will search all the default locations as suggested by kubernetes). We are still unclear on what is causing the 3rd party CI to fail. if there is a way for us to access the logs, that would really help.'}, {'account_id': 18476, 'date': '2017-12-01 22:19:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 92.'}, {'account_id': 26201, 'date': '2017-12-01 22:19:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 92:

Change-Id: I5413ee490a0c2266b720082dcd88e1a687f3f28f
'}, {'created': '2017-09-28 16:20:44.000000000', 'message': 'Ceph OSD disk targeting

This allows users to configure ceph such that an OSD pod will
be created fror each device that is provided.

OSD devices and journals may be specified either using paths to
block device files or with SCSI paths of the form "scsi@x:y:z:n".
Journal devices may also have a partition specified either as
part of the device name or as a separate value.

The patch also updates liveness and readiness checks to be more
appropriate for an environment with multiple OSDs per host.

Change-Id: I5413ee490a0c2266b720082dcd88e1a687f3f28f

commit_message:
Ceph OSD disk targeting

This allows users to configure ceph such that an OSD pod will
be created fror each device that is provided.

OSD devices and journals may be specified either using paths to
block device files or with SCSI paths of the form "scsi@x:y:z:n".
Journal devices may also have a partition specified either as
part of the device name or as a separate value.

The patch also updates liveness and readiness checks to be more
appropriate for an environment with multiple OSDs per host.

Change-Id: I5413ee490a0c2266b720082dcd88e1a687f3f28f

Add missed probes to octavia-api

* Allow to tune probe parameters via values

Change-Id: I8e7a90ac8c8c78c18d36967ed8f06e5884d5e297

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC

commit_message:
Closes-Bug: 1709524

Added logic to repair invalid or corrupted grstate.dat file

Recover MariaDB cluster after reboot or power cycle
Modifies logical to leverage "safe_to_bootstrap"
In addition, avoid more than one MariaDB nodes from bootstrapping the cluster

Closes-Bug: 1709524

Change-Id: I0430667e8193ea7e2888004110f92e3d89b2345a

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-03-03 02:25:08.000000000', 'message': 'Enable startup probe for mariadb

In some case, we need startup probe for maridb.
The kubelet uses startup probes to know when a Container
application has started. If such a probe is configured,
it disables liveness and readiness checks until it succeeds,
making sure those probes don’t interfere with the application
startup. This can be used to adopt liveness checks on slow
starting containers, avoiding them getting killed by the
kubelet before they are up and running.

Tested pass on StarlingX project.

Change-Id: Ie162180bba2956cab8cb2116afa10dec9469c862
Signed-off-by: Zhipeng Liu <zhipengs.liu@intel.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Enable startup probe for mariadb

In some case, we need startup probe for maridb.
The kubelet uses startup probes to know when a Container
application has started. If such a probe is configured,
it disables liveness and readiness checks until it succeeds,
making sure those probes don’t interfere with the application
startup. This can be used to adopt liveness checks on slow
starting containers, avoiding them getting killed by the
kubelet before they are up and running.

Tested pass on StarlingX project.

Change-Id: Ie162180bba2956cab8cb2116afa10dec9469c862
Signed-off-by: Zhipeng Liu <zhipengs.liu@intel.com>

commit_message:
Add liveness probe for mariadb

* refactor _readiness probe to support liveness and readiness check
* for liveness probe check mysqld pid, fail in case of 3x180 seconds

Related-Prod: PRODX-3371
Change-Id: I469b033a2f9f8985de95c75cb0674c4a7941de6a

commit_message:
Add OCI annotations to loci images

Add OCI annotations according to
https://github.com/opencontainers/image-spec/blob/master/annotations.md

Also pass commit hash instead of provided reference to build arguments
to ensure that annotation revision matches actual one.

Change-Id: I41ad467a3de3501b47bbae2369d967e963e8fc14

The default daemonset is targeted to all other nodes that do not much
overrides targets. In this case original targets for default daemonset
are ignored. The patch adds ability to do not create default daemonset
by specifying Values.conf.overrides.<ds-name>.overrides_default boolean

Change-Id: Ie4d4746a88ea47e51f8a7703c8c1971b6f6df78b
'}]
commit_message:
Add ability to do not create -default daemonset with overrides

The default daemonset is targeted to all other nodes that do not much
overrides targets. In this case original targets for default daemonset
are ignored. The patch adds ability to do not create default daemonset
by specifying Values.conf.overrides.<ds-name>.overrides_default boolean
flag which will allow to explicitly specify all needed configuration and
theirs target combinations via overrides.

Change-Id: Ie4d4746a88ea47e51f8a7703c8c1971b6f6df78b

subject: Bring in apache wsgi/security configs
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 7769, 'name': 'Pentheus', 'display_name': 'Alan Meadows', 'email': 'alan.meadows@gmail.com', 'username': 'alanmeadows'}, {'_account_id': 8898, 'name': 'Chris Wedgwood', 'email': 'cw@f00f.org', 'username': 'anticw'}, {'_account_id': 12281, 'name': 'Itxaka', 'email': 'igarcia@suse.com', 'username': 'itxaka'}, {'_account_id': 16771, 'name': 'mpolenchuk', 'email': 'mpolenchuk@mirantis.com', 'username': 'mpolenchuk'}, {'_account_id': 17591, 'name': 'Steve Wilkerson', 'email': 'wilkers.steve@gmail.com', 'username': 'srwilkers'}, {'_account_id': 20466, 'name': 'Tin Lam', 'email': 'tin@lam.wtf', 'username': 'tinlam'}, {'_account_id': 21420, 'name': 'Gage Hugo', 'email': 'gagehugo@gmail.com', 'username': 'ghugo'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 22477, 'name': 'Matt McEuen', 'email': 'matt.mceuen@att.com', 'username': 'mattmceuen'}, {'_account_id': 23928, 'name': 'Pete Birley', 'email': 'petebirley@gmail.com', 'username': 'portdirect'}, {'_account_id': 30777, 'name': 'Steven Fitzpatrick', 'email': 'steven@fitzpatrick.wtf', 'username': 'sf280x'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 16771, 'date': '2020-02-21 11:43:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 20466, 'date': '2020-02-21 15:25:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

How are these being used? Also, what if someone wants to override it (e.g. they need some new security header) do they need to build a new HTK?'}, {'account_id': 16771, 'date': '2020-02-26 09:08:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> How are these being used? Also, what if someone wants to override
 > it (e.g. they need some new security header) do they need to build
 > a new HTK?

The example of usage could be taken from https://review.opendev.org/709988
Overriding will be as usual (template in values).'}, {'account_id': 16771, 'date': '2020-03-06 08:10:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

ready to get merged'}, {'account_id': 23928, 'date': '2020-03-17 15:24:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

is there a reason this cannot be done via similar methods for what has been done for keystone etc? I'm somewhat concerned re the opinionation that this introduces to apache config."}, {'account_id': 16771, 'date': '2020-03-18 07:28:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> is there a reason this cannot be done via similar methods for what
 > has been done for keystone etc? I'm somewhat concerned re the
 > opinionation that this introduces to apache config.

It's just intended to re-use common code in other services since this configs will be the same most of the time."}, {'account_id': 30777, 'date': '2020-03-18 15:54:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

It seems like the OSH Keystone and Cinder charts handle their httpd configuration a bit differently than how I'm used to seeing it done in OSH-Infra, but I think there are advantages to defining this directly in the values.yaml file for now.

Do we expect many new charts to be added to OSH which could take advantage of this htk snippet, or would this mainly be backported to existing charts?

The configuration will be more explicit, and easier to override, if it is defined directly in values.yaml rather than by htk. I like that you provided some parameters to make it configurable, but the usage of the template is a bit hard to read - The only way to interpret ( tuple "Prod" "Off" "Off" ) is to first read the htk file. Do these parameters provide all the configuration needed for this snippet to be dropped in to existing charts?

One last observation: The bulk of the text in this configuration is comments. If brevity is desired these could be trimmed in my opinion.'}, {'account_id': 21420, 'date': '2021-04-15 18:53:11.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

Abandoning since there hasn't been any recent activity, if anyone wants to continue this work, please feel free to restore this or create a new change."}]

This plugin is starting to seem fragile, given how many exceptions we're trying to catch just to determine why Elasticsearch didn't respond how we expected. subject: Move flake8 as a pre-commit local target.
messages: [{'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2021-04-15 14:51:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2021-04-15 14:51:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2021-04-15 16:07:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-04-15 14:51:04.000000000', 'message': "Move flake8 as a pre-commit local target.

The goal here is to avoid conflicts between flake8 and hacking version each
2 days.

Inspired from nova's approach[1].

The flake8 version to install will be determined by hacking and
requirements[2] will stay aligned instead of relying on different versions.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/src/branch/master/.pre-commit-config.yaml#L26-L35
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/hacking/src/branch/master/requirements.txt#L1

Co-authored-by: Daniel Bengtsson <dbengt@redhat.com>

Change-Id: I3d2e95c783cb0ca88ea8657acd9f262ea9244e9d
(cherry picked from commit f43a70687cf9e4704612780f2e8d026661d2aae1)
"}]
commit_message:
Move flake8 as a pre-commit local target.

The goal here is to avoid conflicts between flake8 and hacking version each
2 days.

Inspired from nova's approach[1].

The flake8 version to install will be determined by hacking and
requirements[2] will stay aligned instead of relying on different versions.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/src/branch/master/.pre-commit-config.yaml#L26-L35
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/hacking/src/branch/master/requirements.txt#L1

Co-authored-by: Daniel Bengtsson <dbengt@redhat.com>

Change-Id: I3d2e95c783cb0ca88ea8657acd9f262ea9244e9d
(cherry picked from commit f43a70687cf9e4704612780f2e8d026661d2aae1)

commit_message:
[Rally] drop unused ks_service/ks_endpoints jobs

Rally doesn't have service this patch drops unneeded jobs that
create service/endpoint/user for rally in keystone.

 * update db_init and bootstrap images to be consistent
   with other charts

Change-Id: I2c92039fd99e4195f08a1da7198ecc4663fe9d5e

commit_message:
Add authentication support respecting Www-authenticate headers.

This change adds support for token creation using headers provided
by the server. This does not provide any credentials, but should
support locally hosted docker registries such as gitlab that
have publicly accessible images.

Change-Id: Id1b6d4fcac8bbc27074febb8c4fc94fee7c416f0

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/wallaby

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/wallaby branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I904a35f3ed9fc64e9414c8cd8c40ac0fed51315a

commit_message:
Update master for stable/wallaby

Add file to the reno documentation build to show release notes for
stable/wallaby.

Use pbr instruction to increment the minor version number
automatically so that master versions are higher than the versions on
stable/wallaby.

Sem-Ver: feature
Change-Id: Ife270ffd6fb617711cd1b5e73882b02ee1aa3fe0

subject: Move flake8 as a pre-commit local target.
messages: [{'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2021-04-15 15:08:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2021-04-15 15:10:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2021-04-15 16:12:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-04-15 15:08:38.000000000', 'message': "Move flake8 as a pre-commit local target.

The goal here is to avoid conflicts between flake8 and hacking version each
2 days.

Inspired from nova's approach[1].

The flake8 version to install will be determined by hacking and
requirements[2] will stay aligned instead of relying on different versions.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/src/branch/master/.pre-commit-config.yaml#L26-L35
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/hacking/src/branch/master/requirements.txt#L1

Change-Id: Ie1d59a73d47d8042d669304da802b9f9a34a81a9
(cherry picked from commit 900692743eaf8c3a9bb1e797757c79843e0940e3)
"}]
commit_message:
Move flake8 as a pre-commit local target.

The goal here is to avoid conflicts between flake8 and hacking version each
2 days.

Inspired from nova's approach[1].

The flake8 version to install will be determined by hacking and
requirements[2] will stay aligned instead of relying on different versions.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/src/branch/master/.pre-commit-config.yaml#L26-L35
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/hacking/src/branch/master/requirements.txt#L1

Change-Id: Ie1d59a73d47d8042d669304da802b9f9a34a81a9
(cherry picked from commit 900692743eaf8c3a9bb1e797757c79843e0940e3)

subject: Support ingress creation for keystone admin endpoint
messages:
[{'account_id': 28676, 'date': '2019-12-05 16:58:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 8898, 'date': '2019-12-31 18:59:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Patch Set 1 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 21420, 'date': '2020-01-08 16:49:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

Is this something for keystone v2? There's not really separate "admin" and "public" endpoints anymore with the v3 API, it's all on the same endpoint.'}, {'account_id': 28676, 'date': '2020-01-22 19:26:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> Is this something for keystone v2? There's not really separate
 > "admin" and "public" endpoints anymore with the v3 API, it's all on
 > the same endpoint.

 > Is this something for keystone v2? There's not really separate
 > "admin" and "public" endpoints anymore with the v3 API, it's all on
 > the same endpoint.

This is for V3. Yes there is no distinguish among internal, admin and public endpoint anymore. But a deployment can create multiple endpoints based on their use cases. For us in StarlingX project, we create all three endpoints, with public endpoint for end users (whose fqdn can be overridden by a system tool provided by StarlingX sysinv), internal endpoint for containerized openstack services within the Kubernetes cluster (it's not accessible from outside of the cluster at all), and admin endpoint for administration purpose on a separate management network. So they serve different users on different networks.   

For the admin endpoint, it's on an administration network exposed to outside of the cluster, not accessible by end users, and it has to be overridable independently. This is why we need the ingress creation for admin endpoint.'}, {'account_id': 21420, 'date': '2021-04-15 18:37:33.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

Abandoning since there hasn't been any recent activity, if anyone wants to continue this work, please feel free to restore this or create a new change."}]

This update added support to create ingress for custom keystone admin
endpoint. It can be used by deployment to expose keystone admin endpoint
to outside of the cluster by ingress.

Change-Id: I49bbec247248fef76cd4c46fad35e3022fe58983
Story: 2006588
Task: 37747
Signed-off-by: Andy Ning <andy.ning@windriver.com>
'}, {'created': '2019-12-31 18:59:25.000000000', 'message': 'Support ingress creation for keystone admin endpoint

This update added support to create ingress for custom keystone admin
endpoint. It can be used by deployment to expose keystone admin endpoint
to outside of the cluster by ingress.

Change-Id: I49bbec247248fef76cd4c46fad35e3022fe58983
Story: 2006588
Task: 37747
Signed-off-by: Andy Ning <andy.ning@windriver.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Support ingress creation for keystone admin endpoint

This update added support to create ingress for custom keystone admin
endpoint. It can be used by deployment to expose keystone admin endpoint
to outside of the cluster by ingress.

Change-Id: I49bbec247248fef76cd4c46fad35e3022fe58983
Story: 2006588
Task: 37747
Signed-off-by: Andy Ning <andy.ning@windriver.com>

commit_message:
fix nova-cell-setup for support rocky and above version

The nova-cell-setup isn't working properly on rocky and stein release.
This PS fixes unlimited waiting of nova-cell-setup during install rocky
and above versions.

commit_message:
Add libvirt ingress network policy overrides

This patch set introduces the ingress network policy overrides
for libvirt.

Please note: there is currently a deficiency in K8s network policy in
that it does not always work properly when the pod uses host-network.

Change-Id: Icf2a7a729af0f74b37c0d5a6e08576169a1d1c8a

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/wallaby

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/wallaby branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: Ie335a6ce2b63e1f7a7ad7a8869fbbae2dfc9b3a7

commit_message:
This ps adds in cleanup to RPC/socket readiness probes.

Without this, rabbitmq logs unexpected connection disconnects
and keeps sockets open until the tcp timeout.

Change-Id: Ie793f5dbaa227c4a90df89ce6d3ff6ccfeeab16f

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-04-06 15:33:41.000000000', 'message': 'Always update the local certmonger ca cert

The local certmonger cert will renew after half its lifetime, which will
be after 6 months by default.  The current code would extract the CA cert
to a PEM file (and trust it), only if the cert in the existing PEM file
was expired.

But this means that the certmonger local cert could be renewed after six
months and not be replaced in the PEM file until the existing cert
expired at the end of the year.  If certs are issued in this time, they
will not be trusted and the update will fail.

This patch removes this condition, so that the extracted and trusted cert
always matches what is in the PEM file, and what is trusted.

Note, this only place this occurs is on the undercloud - because this is
where we could use the certmonger local cert.  We assume that the haproxy
cert will be re-issued in an update.

Change-Id: If804dc369c5883eeb51f7e6dcd01ee0e5967c7cf
'}]
commit_message:
Always update the local certmonger ca cert

The local certmonger cert will renew after half its lifetime, which will
be after 6 months by default.  The current code would extract the CA cert
to a PEM file (and trust it), only if the cert in the existing PEM file
was expired.

But this means that the certmonger local cert could be renewed after six
months and not be replaced in the PEM file until the existing cert
expired at the end of the year.  If certs are issued in this time, they
will not be trusted and the update will fail.

This patch removes this condition, so that the extracted and trusted cert
always matches what is in the PEM file, and what is trusted.

Note, this only place this occurs is on the undercloud - because this is
where we could use the certmonger local cert.  We assume that the haproxy
cert will be re-issued in an update.

Change-Id: If804dc369c5883eeb51f7e6dcd01ee0e5967c7cf

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/wallaby

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/wallaby branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: If5c356c4ecc213b8a7957890b143d9030a974860

commit_message:
Create keystone federations

The patch adds ability to configure keystone federations at
deployment/installation stage. Structure in values which defines is
created according to keystone /v3/OS-FEDERATION API
https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/identity/v3-ext/?expanded=register-an-identity-provider-detail,add-protocol-to-identity-provider-detail,create-a-mapping-detail#os-federation-api
So according to above it could be easily reworked to use API and JSON
format to configure it by API directly instead of by CLI commands.

Change-Id: Ib29c9b05203456c7f23d0d44443c07fa26362400

commit_message:
UCP: PostgreSQL: Support for configuration of log levels

This change is to enable log levels in postgresql.

The log records generated should consist of as many of the following information as possible

a. Timestamp

b. Filename

c. line no

d. Log level

e. Function name

Change-Id: I05a92203586879f51d4b9f84b43549a344467e2e

subject: libvirt: Ignore device already in the process of unplug errors
messages:
[{'account_id': 10135, 'date': '2021-04-09 17:14:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10135, 'date': '2021-04-09 17:18:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 10135, 'date': '2021-04-09 17:22:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 26515, 'date': '2021-04-09 19:52:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Build succeeded. For checking Nova with Ceph, add a comment with run-Cloudbase Nova Ceph Hyper-V CI

- nova http://cloudbase-ci.com/nova/785682/3/iscsi : SUCCESS in 2h 28m 50s'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2021-04-10 01:34:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2

(2 comments)

Looks sensible to me. Took me awhile to understand that QEMU itself is erroneously trying another delete while a delete is already in progress.

So this patch makes sense, just catch and ignore this case and retry until the device is reported MISSING which will cause us to raise DeviceNotFound. We will continue on to disconnect the device from the host via cinder (if this is a volume) if we catch DeviceNotFound, so we won't miss that step either."}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2021-04-15 12:29:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

OK this make sense to me. I will adapt the https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/770246 to handle this case too.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-04-09 17:14:03.000000000', 'message': 'libvirt: Ignore device already in the process of unplug errors

At present QEMU will raise an error to libvirt when a device_del request
is made for a device that has already partially detached through a
previous request. This is outlined in more detail in the following
downstream Red Hat QEMU bug report:

Get libvirtError "Device XX is already in the process of unplug" [..]
https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1878659

Within Nova we can actually ignore this error and allow our existing
retry logic to attempt again after a short wait, hopefully allowing the
original request to complete removing the device from the domain.

This change does this and should result in one of the following
device_del requests resulting in a VIR_ERR_DEVICE_MISSING error from
libvirt. _try_detach_device should then translate that libvirt error
into a DeviceNotFound exception within Nova which is then ignored by all
callers detach_device_with_retry and taken to mean that the device has
detached successfully.

Closes-Bug: #1923206
Change-Id: I0e068043d8267ab91535413d950a3e154c2234f7
'}, {'created': '2021-04-09 17:18:02.000000000', 'message': 'libvirt: Ignore device already in the process of unplug errors

commit_message:
libvirt: Ignore device already in the process of unplug errors

At present QEMU will raise an error to libvirt when a device_del request
is made for a device that has already partially detached through a
previous request. This is outlined in more detail in the following
downstream Red Hat QEMU bug report:

Get libvirtError "Device XX is already in the process of unplug" [..]
https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1878659

Within Nova we can actually ignore this error and allow our existing
retry logic to attempt again after a short wait, hopefully allowing the
original request to complete removing the device from the domain.

This change does this and should result in one of the following
device_del requests raising a VIR_ERR_DEVICE_MISSING error from libvirt.
_try_detach_device should then translate that libvirt error into a
DeviceNotFound exception which is itself then ignored by all
detach_device_with_retry callers and taken to mean that the device has
detached successfully.

Closes-Bug: #1923206
Change-Id: I0e068043d8267ab91535413d950a3e154c2234f7

commit_message:
WIP:enhance: support macos devel environment

Because macos environment is populor, as develer, i like to try the helm
repo in my devel box, this ps can fix some bug for install
openstack-helm on macos all in one.

1. support openstack-aio development setup
2. upgrade docker-py to docker, latest docker python package.

Change-Id: I503321b5ca5a7b627d65c3a4bcaba6bd046f97a6
Signed-off-by: Deshi Xiao <xiaods@gmail.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-04-15 14:57:14.000000000', 'message': "Move flake8 as a pre-commit local target.

The goal here is to avoid conflicts between flake8 and hacking version each
2 days.

Inspired from nova's approach[1].

The flake8 version to install will be determined by hacking and
requirements[2] will stay aligned instead of relying on different versions.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/src/branch/master/.pre-commit-config.yaml#L26-L35
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/hacking/src/branch/master/requirements.txt#L1

Change-Id: I27da03673da0663c77948d9193e74fc0e906632e
(cherry picked from commit c587b7ead8895b66c2e07fb2d4388aaa3d934929)
"}]
commit_message:
Move flake8 as a pre-commit local target.

The goal here is to avoid conflicts between flake8 and hacking version each
2 days.

Inspired from nova's approach[1].

The flake8 version to install will be determined by hacking and
requirements[2] will stay aligned instead of relying on different versions.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/src/branch/master/.pre-commit-config.yaml#L26-L35
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/hacking/src/branch/master/requirements.txt#L1

Change-Id: I27da03673da0663c77948d9193e74fc0e906632e
(cherry picked from commit c587b7ead8895b66c2e07fb2d4388aaa3d934929)

commit_message:
Move flake8 as a pre-commit local target.

The goal here is to avoid conflicts between flake8 and hacking version each
2 days.

Inspired from nova's approach[1].

The flake8 version to install will be determined by hacking and
requirements[2] will stay aligned instead of relying on different versions.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/src/branch/master/.pre-commit-config.yaml#L26-L35
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/hacking/src/branch/master/requirements.txt#L1

Change-Id: I831311270134dfa592b02497701d9aee0100607d
(cherry picked from commit 0bbb22a72bf25b52524f5c7b9f2d5df43d2ed24e)

subject: Fix requirements issues.
messages: [{'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2021-04-15 14:53:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2021-04-15 14:55:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2021-04-15 16:09:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-04-15 14:53:37.000000000', 'message': "Fix requirements issues.

This patch is the merge of 2 current fixes that need to be solved in the
same time. Indeed each issue lock our gates independently.

Dropping lower constraints testing

We facing errors related to the new pip resolver, this
topic was discussed on the ML and QA team proposed to
to test lower-constraints [1].

I propose to drop this test because the complexity and recurring pain needed
to maintain that now exceeds the benefits provided by this mechanismes.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-December/019390.html

Move flake8 as a pre-commit local target.

The goal here is to avoid conflicts between flake8 and hacking version each
2 days.

Inspired from nova's approach[1].

The flake8 version to install will be determined by hacking and
requirements[2] will stay aligned instead of relying on different versions.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/src/branch/master/.pre-commit-config.yaml#L26-L35
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/hacking/src/branch/master/requirements.txt#L1

Co-authored-by: Daniel Bengtsson <dbengt@redhat.com>

Change-Id: Ia349eba36d8556d4d2775a83b9a344b2ebeed972
(cherry picked from commit 5f5db610c64aefc7b703b142271c7d52e000c108)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix requirements issues.

This patch is the merge of 2 current fixes that need to be solved in the
same time. Indeed each issue lock our gates independently.

Dropping lower constraints testing

We facing errors related to the new pip resolver, this
topic was discussed on the ML and QA team proposed to
to test lower-constraints [1].

I propose to drop this test because the complexity and recurring pain needed
to maintain that now exceeds the benefits provided by this mechanismes.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-December/019390.html

Move flake8 as a pre-commit local target.

The goal here is to avoid conflicts between flake8 and hacking version each
2 days.

Inspired from nova's approach[1].

The flake8 version to install will be determined by hacking and
requirements[2] will stay aligned instead of relying on different versions.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/src/branch/master/.pre-commit-config.yaml#L26-L35
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/hacking/src/branch/master/requirements.txt#L1

Co-authored-by: Daniel Bengtsson <dbengt@redhat.com>

Change-Id: Ia349eba36d8556d4d2775a83b9a344b2ebeed972
(cherry picked from commit 5f5db610c64aefc7b703b142271c7d52e000c108)

subject: Enhancements to make stats cachedump configurable
messages:
[{'account_id': 33282, 'date': '2021-04-07 00:25:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 30449, 'date': '2021-04-07 00:54:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

--disable-dumping，Will this lead to some security issues？'}, {'account_id': 33282, 'date': '2021-04-07 13:45:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1
> 
> --disable-dumping，Will this lead to some security issues？

No. The cachedump is enabled by default that will cause security issues. This patchset is to disable that functionality to prevent user obtaining the sensitive info.'}, {'account_id': 33282, 'date': '2021-04-07 13:45:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 33282, 'date': '2021-04-07 13:49:48.000000000', 'content': 'Set Work In Progress'}, {'account_id': 33282, 'date': '2021-04-07 15:13:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

This change is ready for review.'}, {'account_id': 33282, 'date': '2021-04-07 15:35:17.000000000', 'content': 'Set Work In Progress'}, {'account_id': 18250, 'date': '2021-04-07 15:43:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Can you share more about this "-X" option?  I can't seems to find it.  
Why is there a need to disable stats cachedump, what problem is this preventing?
Another suggestion is to make "non-mandatory" parameters such as this configurable, either turn them on via a knob in values, or simply add an override capability so user can any extra parameters they want, instead of having to hardcode this everywhere.'}, {'account_id': 33282, 'date': '2021-04-07 23:21:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1
> 
> Can you share more about this "-X" option?  I can't seems to find it.  
> Why is there a need to disable stats cachedump, what problem is this preventing?
> Another suggestion is to make "non-mandatory" parameters such as this configurable, either turn them on via a knob in values, or simply add an override capability so user can any extra parameters they want, instead of having to hardcode this everywhere.

The stats cachedump is enabled by default. With cachedump functionality, user can obtain sensitive info. For info about the options, please refer to http://manpages.ubuntu.com/manpages/bionic/man1/memcached.1.html, or execute memcached with --help option. The pathset will be updated accordingly to implement the suggested configurable option.'}, {'account_id': 33282, 'date': '2021-04-07 23:21:54.000000000', 'content': 'Set Work In Progress'}, {'account_id': 33282, 'date': '2021-04-08 00:00:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 33282, 'date': '2021-04-08 00:12:31.000000000', 'content': 'Set Ready For Review'}, {'account_id': 33282, 'date': '2021-04-08 16:36:37.000000000', 'content': 'Set Work In Progress'}, {'account_id': 18236, 'date': '2021-04-14 16:05:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 33282, 'date': '2021-04-14 16:14:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
Enhancements to make stats cachedump configurable

Memcached stats cachedump is enabled by default. Changes in this
pathset provide an option to configure stats cachedump as desired
during deployment i.e. the stats cachedump can be disabled to
prevent user obtaining sensitive info via the cachedump data.

Change-Id: Ic6254f89b1478a414ac275436ddd659b16b75f98

This patch is the merge of 2 current fixes that need to be solved in the
same time. Indeed each issue lock our gates independently.

Dropping lower constraints testing

We facing errors related to the new pip resolver, this
topic was discussed on the ML and QA team proposed to
to test lower-constraints [1].

I propose to drop this test because the complexity and recurring pain needed
to maintain that now exceeds the benefits provided by this mechanismes.

commit_message:
Fix requirements issues

This patch is the merge of 2 current fixes that need to be solved in the
same time. Indeed each issue lock our gates independently.

Dropping lower constraints testing

We facing errors related to the new pip resolver, this
topic was discussed on the ML and QA team proposed to
to test lower-constraints [1].

I propose to drop this test because the complexity and recurring pain needed
to maintain that now exceeds the benefits provided by this mechanismes.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-December/019390.html

Move flake8 as a pre-commit local target.

The goal here is to avoid conflicts between flake8 and hacking version each
2 days.

Inspired from nova's approach[1].

The flake8 version to install will be determined by hacking and
requirements[2] will stay aligned instead of relying on different versions.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/src/branch/master/.pre-commit-config.yaml#L26-L35
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/hacking/src/branch/master/requirements.txt#L1

Co-authored-by: Daniel Bengtsson <dbengt@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I04a845fd98f0d21f7a21dae9f184117263390dd1
(cherry picked from commit 7f167721ab6f9b28111b8dbfcaf56ed393bd6b12)

TripleO client and common repos release and branch stable/wallaby

As part of our work to validate the upstream jobs before making
a full stable/wallaby for all our repos, lets cut tripleo-common
and python-tripleoclient branches for early testing.

Pass existing DB obj to save DB requests

On port and network update ML2 plugin gets a db object
and can pass it to db_base_plugin_v2 when doing super call.

commit_message:
Move flake8 as a pre-commit local target.

The goal here is to avoid conflicts between flake8 and hacking version each
2 days.

Inspired from nova's approach[1].

The flake8 version to install will be determined by hacking and
requirements[2] will stay aligned instead of relying on different versions.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/src/branch/master/.pre-commit-config.yaml#L26-L35
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/hacking/src/branch/master/requirements.txt#L1

Change-Id: I383111df27815708b60bf93ab565e402bb42d230
(cherry picked from commit 2193fcc2e41416e9fb3a3cf01f6b2afb8ead2d56)

Install the latest version of hacking to fix the conflict error with the
pre-commit hook

Original fix by Daniel Bengtsson

Change-Id: I3d2e95c783cb0ca88ea8657acd9f262ea9244e9d

commit_message:
Move flake8 as a pre-commit local target.

The goal here is to avoid conflicts between flake8 and hacking version each
2 days.

Inspired from nova's approach[1].

The flake8 version to install will be determined by hacking and
requirements[2] will stay aligned instead of relying on different versions.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/src/branch/master/.pre-commit-config.yaml#L26-L35
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/hacking/src/branch/master/requirements.txt#L1

Co-authored-by: Daniel Bengtsson <dbengt@redhat.com>

Change-Id: I3d2e95c783cb0ca88ea8657acd9f262ea9244e9d

commit_message:
Pass multipath config while creating connector object

Currently we only pass the configured multipath option when getting
the connector properties and do not pass it when creating the
connector object which in turn does the multipathing in os-brick.
So we are only passing multipathing option to cinder for exporting &
mapping the volume to paths but not while creating the connector object
and hence doing multipathing partially.
This patch passes that option and fixes the stated issue.

Related-Bug: #1863983

Co-Authored-By: Gorka Eguileor <geguileo@redhat.com>

Change-Id: I82979c47ec9ec1dd6cc864d3827ab219177251f8

commit_message:
Fix requirements issues

This patch is the merge of 2 current fixes that need to be solved in the
same time. Indeed each issue lock our gates independently.

Dropping lower constraints testing

We facing errors related to the new pip resolver, this
topic was discussed on the ML and QA team proposed to
to test lower-constraints [1].

I propose to drop this test because the complexity and recurring pain needed
to maintain that now exceeds the benefits provided by this mechanismes.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-December/019390.html

Move flake8 as a pre-commit local target.

The goal here is to avoid conflicts between flake8 and hacking version each
2 days.

Inspired from nova's approach[1].

The flake8 version to install will be determined by hacking and
requirements[2] will stay aligned instead of relying on different versions.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/src/branch/master/.pre-commit-config.yaml#L26-L35
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/hacking/src/branch/master/requirements.txt#L1

Co-authored-by: Daniel Bengtsson <dbengt@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I04a845fd98f0d21f7a21dae9f184117263390dd1

commit_message:
Move flake8 as a pre-commit local target.

The goal here is to avoid conflicts between flake8 and hacking version
each 2 days.

Inspired from nova's approach [1].

The flake8 version to install will be determined by hacking and
requirements [2] will stay aligned instead of relying on different
versions.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/src/branch/master/.pre-commit-config.yaml#L26-L35
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/hacking/src/branch/master/requirements.txt#L1

Change-Id: I29daa7205fc28e2768792c24fa054257e9f66674
(cherry picked from commit 1f5c95272e48633a3fce4db573258d015c14f238)

commit_message:
[OVN] Remove check for OVN + Availability Zones

The ML2/OVN driver does support AZ-aware routing scheduling from
stable/train and newer versions.

This patch also removes the check from the DHCP agent container because
although not a typical deployment, the Neutron DHCP agent can be
deployed with OVN for special cases such as baremetal provisioning where
the agent would serve DHCP to the baremetal instances.

Change-Id: I8941c4d9a8e68eb775c910495de4aff9fbc67206
Signed-off-by: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com>
(cherry picked from commit 9283e44d16214f148e04a66d248514b170dad07f)

commit_message:
Fix requirements issues

This patch is the merge of 2 current fixes that need to be solved in the
same time. Indeed each issue lock our gates independently.

Dropping lower constraints testing

We facing errors related to the new pip resolver, this
topic was discussed on the ML and QA team proposed to
to test lower-constraints [1].

I propose to drop this test because the complexity and recurring pain needed
to maintain that now exceeds the benefits provided by this mechanismes.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-December/019390.html

Move flake8 as a pre-commit local target.

The goal here is to avoid conflicts between flake8 and hacking version each
2 days.

Inspired from nova's approach[1].

The flake8 version to install will be determined by hacking and
requirements[2] will stay aligned instead of relying on different versions.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/src/branch/master/.pre-commit-config.yaml#L26-L35
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/hacking/src/branch/master/requirements.txt#L1

Co-authored-by: Hervé Beraud <hberaud@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Ic2242c5fc9d3bd03b87d9728449c3eb6e1ce8043
